Tweet: After 35 years as a college professor, I see the introduction of firearms on to college campuses as a potential disaster. This is an environment in which young people, often for the first time in theri lives, are trying to navigate their way through the world at large. Examinations, personal relationships, and other factors create stresses, in some cases more than they can cope with. I would not like to face a student who feels aggrieved about a bad grade in the likelihood that they might have a firearm under their jacket. Nor should in classroom discussions, often heated at times, be conducted under such an environment. No, college is a place where children come to become adults, and minimizing threats of violence is one of the controls that we need to make to make this passage safer.
Wiki: the document argues that the introduction of firearms on college campuses could lead to a potential disaster. the college environment is a place where young people are trying to navigate their way through the world, often facing stress from exams and personal relationships. the author believes that having firearms on campus could lead to an increase in violent situations, making it unsafe for students and faculty. the author emphasizes the importance of maintaining a safe and nonviolent environment in order for students to successfully transition from children to adults. abbreviations, slang, and hashtags have not been used in the document.

Tweet: Few here seem to realize the one belief all Federal Judges share: The rule of law is first and foremost a tool to serve business. It's part of the reason the Justices often get on so well personally. The letter of the law did not radically change concerning same sex marriage, but the attitudes of the great majority of the citizenry did and doing business became more difficult for companies doing business in states that stubbornly held on to the last century's prejudices. So the Supreme Court had a eureka moment and ruled gay people had the same rights as the rest of the American People. Donald Trump has famously promised, if elected, to use the power of the Oval Office to drag his enemies through the courts. How is that arbitrary application of power to be seen as anything but a descent into corruption and an end to rule of law and the beginning of the rule of tyrants? Do we really want to have to pay off every government official to sell shoes, bake donuts or build cars? Justice Ginsburg does not want that kind of nation, and for one, I'm glad she said so.

Tweet: "Should guns be allowed on campuses" is a perverse question. I would like to ask first: are guns allowed in colleges anywhere else in the world? Are more student dying there as a result of shootings? The answer of course is NO in both cases. Did anyone really need to debate about this? Just the idea that someone can think about something like this is sick and a sign of a dangerous deterioration of the expectations we as a so called civilized society have about each another. The other question is: why are so many shootings happening in USA campuses? Why are Americans in such pain that they need to overdose on opioids or/and shoot each other?
Wiki: the document argues that the question of whether guns should be allowed on college campuses is troubling. the author points out that guns are not allowed in colleges elsewhere in the world, and that there are fewer student deaths from shootings in those places. the author finds it disturbing that there is even a debate about this issue. the document also raises the question of why there are so many shootings on us college campuses and why americans are in such distress that they turn to opioid overdoses and violence. the author expresses concern about the decline of expectations in society and the need for a civilized approach to these issues. the document uses the abbreviation "usa" for the united states of america. the slang term "overdose on opioids" refers to taking too many opioid drugs. there are no hashtags in the document.

Tweet: Greece has put up with a lot of suffering already, the difference between being in or out of the Euro-zone is no longer the wide gulf that it was. Had we known the future of the path set upon 4 years ago they would have been better off jumping ship then. Now, the people have fewer resources with which to endure what's coming but the alternatives offer nothing good in the short run. Long-term, if the Euro survives (a real question in my mind) then Greece will miss out but that's a bet not worth taking at this time. They should exit, sooner rather than later.

- euro-zone: the group of european union countries that have adopted the euro as their official currency 
- #euro: the official currency of the european union 
- #greece: a country in southeastern europe 
- #eu: the european union

Tweet: Blue collar jobs: My plumber and electrician are both smart guys and seem to do well financially. My hairdresser has somehow amassed enough money to buy and sell large pieces of real estate. I know a young man who makes plenty in his window-washing business, and another friend, who works on computers with a technical-school education, has a house bigger than mine (I have a PhD). A couple of decades ago, we had an addition built on our house, and we used a highly recommended contractor. He told us that, when he graduated from high school, he took the money his father had saved for his college and started a business instead. He is still in business, probably has not had time for college. He has been successful and does good work. I would never minimize the importance of college for those who have a reason to go, but I can't agree with the one-size-fits-all philosophy. There are plenty of important jobs to be done that don't involve college; there are other kinds of skill and knowledge we all depend on.
Wiki:
the document highlights the fact that blue collar workers such as plumbers, electricians, hairdressers, window washers, and contractors can be financially successful without having a college education. it challenges the idea that a college degree is necessary for success and emphasizes the importance of different types of skills and knowledge. it also suggests that there are plenty of important jobs that don't require a college education. the document implies that individuals in blue-collar jobs can have a good income and achieve financial success. it stresses that there are multiple paths to success and that a one-size-fits-all approach is not sufficient. 

abbreviations and slang expanded:
- phd: doctor of philosophy
- #college: college education
- window-washing: the act of cleaning windows
- highly recommended: highly praised or well-regarded

hashtags do not need to be expanded as they are already full phrases.

Wiki: the document discusses the success and financial stability of individuals in blue collar jobs, such as plumbers, electricians, hairdressers, window washers, and contractors. it challenges the belief that a college degree is necessary for financial success and highlights the value of alternative paths, such as technical school education and starting a business. the author believes that there are plenty of important jobs that don't require college and emphasizes the different kinds of skills and knowledge that are essential in these professions. the author also shares personal experiences with individuals who have found success without pursuing a traditional college education. overall, the document sheds light on the idea of college alternatives and the different paths to financial success and fulfillment.

Tweet: I agree that not everyone needs French, and frankly not everyone desires to learn French. There should be a supply/demand system to which language classes to offer at a certain school. Growing up, the only choice we had was Spanish in all our public schools. Why? In a border state, it was the most useful. French is not a very useful language in the US, unless you plan on working abroad or in Canada. I don't condone removing languages entirely from education (learning any language is a useful skill), but in order to make the most of a person's time and his/her desire to learn a certain language, then offer what has the highest demand, probably these days Spanish and Mandarin, the two most spoken languages globally ahead of English. The supply/demand system should be duly noted when choosing whether a humanities degree is desirable. Is it really in demand in today's world? I don't think so.
Wiki:
the document suggests that language classes offered at a school should be determined based on supply and demand. the author states that not everyone needs or wants to learn french, and believes that the most useful languages in the us are spanish and mandarin. they argue that the supply and demand system should also be considered when choosing a humanities degree, as they question its desirability and demand in today's world.

the author's suggestions imply that the choice of language classes and a humanities degree should be based on what is most useful and in demand, rather than traditional or less practical options.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document can be expanded into complete phrases and sentences as follows:
- "i don't" can be expanded to "i do not"
- "there should be a supply/demand system" can be expanded to "there should be a system based on the supply and demand"
- "#borderstate" can be expanded to "hashtag border state"

Tweet: My daughter is a college professor who just left employment at a well-known Tennessee university. She gets emails from one or two disgruntled students at the end of every semester complaining about the grade she gave them. What is to stop any of these teenagers, who are proven to have an undeveloped frontal lobe and thus lack the capacity for realizing the consequences of their choices, from bringing a gun to her readily accessible office and shooting her? The student may go to jail, but my daughter will be dead. That is my fear.

"jail" refers to the possibility of the student going to prison if they were to harm the professor. the hashtag #gun implies a conversation about the potential danger of firearms.

Tweet: The fiction of the court being apolitical is evidenced by innumerable decisions where the court breaks along ideological lines (see: Bush v. Gore). Tweet: Mr. Adams, in the absence of regulations, there would be no financial fallout. As an example, auto emissions impose large costs on society i.e., pollution, and on many individuals in society, for example those with respiratory problems. But car manufacturers do not bear those costs - the costs are externalities to the manufacturer. Markets are in general very good at coordinating supply and demand and allocating capital but markets only work if economic actors both receive the benefits but also bear the costs of their business decisions. Regulations, however imperfect, are necessary because, in many circumstances economic actors receive the profits but do not pay the costs of their activity. In such circumstances it is rational for a firm maximize its profits while ignoring the costs, however large, of its business activities. If there were no emissions regulations, including penalties for violating, those regulations, VW would face no financial fallout. They would build diesel cars that maximized their profit and that imposed tremendous costs on everyone else. There would be no incentive whatsoever for them to do anything else.
Wiki: the document argues that in the absence of regulations, there would be no financial consequences for car manufacturers. for example, auto emissions impose significant costs on society and individuals, such as pollution and respiratory problems, but manufacturers do not bear these costs - they are externalities. markets are good at coordinating supply and demand, but they only work if economic actors both receive the benefits and bear the costs of their decisions. regulations, despite their imperfections, are necessary because economic actors often receive profits without paying the costs of their activities. without emissions regulations and penalties for violations, vw would not face any financial consequences and would prioritize maximizing profits, even at the expense of imposing costs on others. this demonstrates the rationality of firms maximizing profits while ignoring the costs of their activities in the absence of regulations.

Tweet: I'm constantly puzzled by the complete absence of any sense of irony in opinions offered by defense professionals. Tweet: The Constitution needs no amending. Very simply, if a person has no photo ID, which, in today's society, makes their alleged inability to vote the least of their problems. then the states should supply one free of charge and just for voting. I doubt the cost would be that substantial to the states as I doubt this is as large a group as the NYT would have us believe. Beyond that, when, in many elections, less than 20% of the registered voters bother to show up in the first place, it would seem that we as voters suppress ourselves far more effectively than any voter ID laws.
Wiki:
the document emphasizes that there is no need to amend the constitution in regards to voting rights. it suggests that if a person does not have a photo id, the state should provide one for free specifically for voting. the writer doubts that the cost would be significant and believes that the group of people without photo ids is not as large as it is portrayed. the document also criticizes voter id laws and argues that voter turnout is low, suggesting that voter suppression comes from voters themselves rather than from id laws. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- nyt: the new york times
- id: identification

Tweet: Personally, I think that priority should be given to those who would use the power of their own legs to get around rather than driving a loud, two ton pollution machine. Don't get me wrong. I'm not saying do away with cars overnight, nor am I saying that it's feasible for everyone to ride a bike wherever they go. But I do think that, eventually, the population will, out of necessity, need to shed the idea that people should drive a car to wherever they need to go forever. The sooner we start encouraging the use of walking and biking, the better off we'll all be.
Wiki:
the document argues that priority should be given to those who use their own legs to get around rather than driving cars. it acknowledges that it may not be feasible for everyone to ride a bike everywhere, but emphasizes the importance of encouraging walking and biking to reduce pollution and dependence on cars.

- feasible: possible to do easily or conveniently
- encouraging: giving support, confidence, or hope to someone
- hashtags: a word or phrase preceded by the symbol #, used to identify messages on a specific topic

when talking about new york, the document implies that the city should prioritize walking and biking over driving to reduce pollution and improve overall well-being.

I'm not saying do away with cars overnight, nor am I saying that it's feasible for everyone to ride a bike wherever they go. But I do think that, eventually, the population will, out of necessity, need to shed the idea that people should drive a car to wherever they need to go forever. The sooner we start encouraging the use of walking and biking, the better off we'll all be.

the document highlights the opinion that priority should be given to those who use their own legs for transportation rather than driving cars, which are seen as loud, polluting machines. the author is not suggesting immediately getting rid of cars, but does believe the population will eventually need to shift away from the idea that driving is the only option. the author encourages the use of walking and biking as the better option for transportation.

in terms of 'new york's bike lane', this document suggests that the city should prioritize developing bike lanes and infrastructure to encourage walking and biking as a means of transportation. it expands the idea that people should use their own legs instead of driving cars, and supports the idea of promoting walking and biking in new york city.

Tweet: I'm a regular, everyday biker. And in my experience, most cities have a variety of acceptable ways to get around on a bike. New York is different. The one-way avenues are hazardous, even for experienced bikers. Other than the West Side Highway, there are actually very few safe routes to take around Manhattan. A few strategically chosen routes can make a big difference here. But there are still not enough safe ways to get through Midtown. Maybe there never will be; Midtown is very congested.

Tweet: "The popular idea that single-sex education benefits women comes from anecdotes about female leaders who were educated in an era when elite colleges did not admit them. For example, Hillary Clinton attended Wellesley College ..." Hillary Rodham graduated from an elite undergraduate institution whose name is Wellesley College. She made a conscious choice to attend, and it is worth saying that at the time she matriculated at Wellesley, other schools did admit women - Penn, Cornell, Brown, Stanford, Berkeley, Michigan, University of Chicago, just to name a few. "There is no data to support the myth that ... graduates [of single-sex colleges] are more likely to choose math-intensive career options." Where are the non-data that support this assertion? I was under the impression that the students at women's colleges major in STEM fields at rates markedly higher than women on coed campuses. What those majoring in STEM fields do career-wise after graduation is, naturally, another issue, particularly today, when students have so many more careers that their parents ever did.

Tweet: Has a Supreme Court Justice in the entire history of the United States ever publicly criticized a presidential candidate? Perhaps I'm wrong but I know of no such instance even during the most divisive period of American life, the Civil War. Justice Taney, for example, never publicly took Lincoln to task, though Lincoln often eviscerated his Dred Scott decision. Nor did Marshall rip into Jefferson though he despised him and said so many times -- privately, that is. What Ginsburg did was disgraceful. I despise Trump and view his election as a potential disaster. But Justices like serving members of the military should remain silent and not enter the political fray. Would those who support Ginsburg's public comments about Trump also support the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff coming out in favor of his election? I strongly doubt it. Indeed, they would probably demand his scalp and they would be right to do so.
Wiki: the document argues that justice ginsburg's public criticism of president trump was disgraceful and inappropriate. the author believes that supreme court justices, like members of the military, should remain silent and not enter the political fray. the author suggests that those who support ginsburg's comments about trump would likely not support the chairman of the joint chiefs of staff coming out in favor of his election, and would demand his removal from office. the author strongly disagrees with ginsburg's actions and feels that they were unjustified.

Tweet: While not all former inmates truly "learn their lesson," I do believe more former inmates come to realize what they've done wrong and desire to live a better life post-time served. It is most unfortunate they are almost always denied of a being able to start a new life solely based on the basis of the fact that they are a "felon." As a current resident in the Commonwealth of Virginia, today I am grateful "Virginia's Governor Terry McAuliffe just restored voting rights to more than 200,000 convicted felons." (source: NYT). People change; people change daily. Before denying a convicted felon of any and all of his/her privileges (e.g. voting rights), why not consider the fact that he/she did serve time of which, was deemed sufficient for his/her crime before coming to a firm decision that convicted felons should not have the right to vote?
Wiki: the document is expressing the belief that many former inmates acknowledge their mistakes and want to live better lives after serving their time. it argues that it is unfair to deny them the chance to start anew simply because they are labeled as "felons." the author is grateful that virginia's governor terry mcauliffe restored voting rights to over 200,000 convicted felons, and emphasizes that people can change. the document suggests that before denying a convicted felon their privileges, such as the right to vote, their rehabilitation and the completion of their sentence should be considered. the use of the term "felon" refers to someone who has been convicted of a serious crime, and the term "commonwealth of virginia" refers to the state of virginia. abbreviations, slang, and hashtags have been expanded in the response.

Tweet: Sorry to argue based on logic, but this is a question about equality before the law. When any group, religious or not, argues that another group does not deserve equality before the law, they are ipso facto arguing against the full valuation of that group as citizens and humans. Tweet: A have a two word solution to the tyranny of billionaire team owners- eminent domain. The value of franchises are sky high because of the ego factor. All the billionaires want one. If they can't be moved nilly willy then they can't extract ransoms from politicians who don't want it to happen to them. Cities, counties or states can lease the rights to manage them to individuals, but they should be held in the commons. Fans pay more and more to attend games, TV audiences sit through unbearable commercials (watch a soccer game- no interruptions) cable costs escalate unendingly. The 49ers priced their blue collar fans out of their new stadium without so much as a thanks. Greed and hubris. I hope I live to see it collapse. I no longer subscribe to cable TV and are trying to wean myself off the game, as well as their minor league (NCAA) offerings.
Wiki:
the document discusses the idea of using eminent domain as a solution to the power and control of billionaire team owners. it suggests that the high value of sports franchises is driven by the ego factor, and that billionaire owners use this to extract ransoms from politicians. the document advocates for the management rights of sports teams to be held in the commons, rather than controlled by individual billionaires. it also criticizes the rising costs for fans, both in attending games and watching on tv, and expresses frustration with the greed and hubris of team owners. the author no longer subscribes to cable tv and is trying to reduce their consumption of sports, as well as college sports offerings.

abbreviations and slang expanded:
- nilly willy -> recklessly
- tv -> television
- 49ers -> san francisco 49ers (american football team)
- ncaa -> national collegiate athletic association

hashtags expanded:
- #eminentdomain -> the power of a government to take private property for public

Tweet: I can see 3D printing for prototypes, and some custom work. However manufacturing industries use thousands of plastics and thousands of metal alloys, few of which can be printed. I don't see that there is going to be a wholesale conversion to this relatively slow, materials-inflexible process.
Wiki: the document suggests that 3d printing is most suitable for making prototypes and custom items. it acknowledges that 3d printing is limited in the range of materials it can work with, particularly in comparison to the vast variety of plastics and metal alloys used in manufacturing industries. it also questions the feasibility of a widespread transition to 3d printing, given its slower production speed and limited material options. it expands the abbreviation "3d" to "three-dimensional," "the slang "wholesale conversion" to "a complete shift," and the hashtag "3dprinting" to "three dimensional printing."

Tweet: Yes! Because just like all sports, it is entertainment! Tweet: To No. 96, I am well aware that current NY law treats bikes and cars as the same and expects bikes to obey the exact same laws as cars. NY law also considers jaywalking a violation of the law and we all know how much those laws are enforced in NYC. If society wants to have laws people respect and obey, they need to be reasonable, enforced, and fairly applied. The current law which attempts to treat bikes the same as vehicles is not reasonable and cannot be enforced in any fair way. Just as it would be impossible to enforce jaywalking laws in NYC. The solution is to change the law, and deal with the real problem - reckless behavior - not whether someone glides through a stop sign or rides safely down a wide one-way street the wrong way (God forbid!) when it presents a danger to no one.
Wiki:
the document acknowledges that current new york law treats bikes and cars the same, expecting bikes to obey the same laws as cars. it also mentions that jaywalking is considered a violation of the law, and highlights the lack of enforcement of these laws in new york city. the document argues that in order for laws to be respected and obeyed, they must be reasonable, enforced, and fairly applied. the current law treating bikes the same as vehicles is deemed unreasonable and impossible to enforce fairly, much like jaywalking laws in nyc. the suggested solution is to change the law and address the real problem of reckless behavior, rather than focusing on minor infractions such as running a stop sign or riding safely down a wide one-way street in a way that does not endanger anyone.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
ny - new york
nyc - new york city

Tweet: City streets and living are not designed for bicycling and therefore should not be used for that purpose. That is what suburban living is about. It is simply a lie that bikes are able to promote a greener city. The traffic backups due to loss of driving lanes are certainly causing the use of increased amounts of gasoline and therefore more toxic emsissions into the air.
Wiki:
the document argues that city streets and living are not meant for bicycling and should not be used for that purpose. it suggests that suburban living is more suitable for biking. it also claims that bikes cannot actually promote a greener city and that the loss of driving lanes for bike lanes causes traffic backups and increases gasoline use and toxic emissions. 

in the context of new york's bike lane, the document implies that the city's streets are not designed for bicycling and that the bike lane may be causing traffic congestion and environmental harm. it suggests that the lack of space for cars due to the bike lane is leading to increased gasoline use and toxic emissions.

Tweet: The day before the massacre I received a cartoon by e-mail from a conservative friend - yes, I lean liberal, but I have many good friends who are quite conservative - that very explicitly managed simultaneously to smear Muslims - ALL Muslims - as being anti-gay while at the same time smearing liberals - ALL liberals - as treating Christian conservatives differently from Muslims when it comes to being anti-gay and implying that we do so out of some misguided sense of political correctness. You, sir, are deeply in denial about both the depth of conservative animus toward people with different values to yours, and about the way in which the conservative community uses that animus to demonize and dehumanize those who disagree with you. Either than, or you just don't care and are willing to say anything to justify continuing down the same path you've been pursuing, which while it is not entirely to blame for what happened in Orlando (and elsewhere) UNQUESTIONABLY contributed to it. You're on the wrong side of history and the wrong side of the moral divide on this - indeed, you're on the wrong side of Christ's teachings, if you really care.

Tweet: Writing can be taught and writing can be assessed. But why are we having this discussion about writing? Why all this talk about how young people can't write? Business leaders want good writers. Yet, teaching writing is considered "the lowest of the low" -- in higher education. Poorly paid adjuncts teach first year composition courses. Writing Centers employ even worse paid tutors (just a little more than minimum wage). So, do we really want good writers -- or don't we?
Wiki:
the document discusses the importance of teaching and assessing writing, and questions why there is so much talk about the lack of writing skills in young people. it points out that business leaders value good writers, yet the teaching of writing is not given high priority in higher education. it brings attention to the poorly paid adjuncts who teach composition courses and the low wages of writing center tutors. the document raises the question of whether society truly values good writers, or if it is just talk.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags are expanded as follows:
- "adjuncts" are part-time or temporary faculty members hired to teach specific courses
- "minimum wage" is the lowest wage permitted by law or by a special agreement
- "do we really want good writers -- or don't we?" is a rhetorical question asking if society genuinely values good writers or not.

Tweet: Spoken like an academic who never bothered dirtying his hands with what he is "researching": "My PhD thesis looks at the evolution of radical transparency mechanisms in terms of both media theory and the governing of democracies. It considers how networked media makes these patterns more complex for both institutions and publics." So disparaging a review of emerging digital technology from one engaged in such enlightened research? Unbecoming. 3-D printing technology is still new and like all technologies will evolve and improve. Remember cell phones 15 years ago? I think you've missed the mark entirely. Tweet: The problem is mobility, and that the individual teams are unregulated utilities. They use mobility and regional loyalty to extract concessions from cities and states or counties. Cities should use eminent domain to seize teams and offer fixed period leases to individuals to manage them. No politician wants to lose a team on their watch, so they willingly pay ransoms. Teams belong to regions, not egotistic billionaires.
Wiki:
the document suggests that cities should use eminent domain, which is the power of the government to take private property for public use, to seize sports teams from unregulated utilities and offer fixed period leases to individuals to manage them. the document also argues that politicians are willing to pay ransoms to keep teams in their city, as no politician wants to lose a team on their watch. additionally, the document emphasizes that teams belong to regions, not egotistic billionaires.

eminent domain is the right of a government to take private property for public use, with compensation to the owner. it is typically used in cases where the property is needed for things such as roads, schools, or other public infrastructure. the document is suggesting that cities should use eminent domain to acquire sports teams and then lease them out to individuals, potentially as a way to prevent the teams from extracting concessions from the city or state. this approach would potentially give the city more control over the teams and their activities.

Tweet: If I wanted to live in Copenhagen I would move there. Tweet: Perhaps rather than forcing greek societies - private organizations controlled individually by charters mandating single-sex admittance - to change their policies, perhaps universities could instead change rules that force fraternities to be the center of social life on campus. Allowing sororities to host parties, for instance, would put women in charge of the distribution of alcohol, which in turn could help to curtail instances of alcohol-related sexual assault. Campuses forcing greek life to go co-ed will lead only to the national chapters of these organizations to suspend their charters at the school. These organizations will, and in my experience have, continue to operate as an underground organization, rather than actually disband; this would only exacerbate the problem, as a secret frat or sorority can be controlled even less than one that operates in the light of day.
Wiki: the document suggests that rather than mandating greek societies to change their single-sex admittance policies, universities should reconsider the rules that make fraternities the center of social life on campus. for example, allowing sororities to host parties could empower women to control the distribution of alcohol and potentially reduce incidents of alcohol-related sexual assault. the document also cautions that forcing greek life to go co-ed could lead national chapters to suspend their charters at the school, causing the organizations to operate underground and exacerbating the problem. instead of disbanding, these secret fraternities and sororities would be even more difficult to regulate.

Tweet: This is the worst article this newspaper has ever run on this issue. The author sets up a ridiculous series of strawmen that do not exist. Wiki: the document criticizes an article in the newspaper for failing to distinguish between legal and illegal immigration and setting up strawman arguments. it argues that immigrants should have responsibilities such as speaking fluent english, not accessing taxpayer-provided assistance, and obeying all laws, including labor laws. it also opposes granting citizenship to immigrants who break the law, suggesting that they should leave the country if they are bothered by this stance. #fugetaboutit is a slang term meaning "forget about it."

Tweet: Mandatory voting would make matters worse. Most of those not voting are making a wise decision since most are not well informed on the issues. It is one that goes to core values of all Americans.

Tweet: 'Free' does not project value. Offering free state university tuition sounds great. Does it solve society problems? Not necessarily! I have seen many students with full federal tuition support due poorly. The distractions and challenges, outside the classroom, still distract them. Plus it is not their money. They did not have to earn or borrow it. There is a tendency for them to withdraw from a class. Free public education impacts the ability of non-profit private colleges to exist. What happens when these institutions crumble? Do state schools have the capacity to pick-up non-profit private school students? Can we afford 'free' across all college students? 'Free' excites us. If it sounds too good to be true . . .
Wiki:
the document discusses how offering free state university tuition may not necessarily solve society's problems. the author has observed that many students who receive full federal tuition support still struggle academically due to distractions and challenges outside the classroom. additionally, since the money is not their own, there is a tendency for them to disengage from their studies. the document also raises concerns about the impact of free public education on non-profit private colleges, and questions whether state schools have the capacity to accommodate students from these institutions if they were to crumble. it also raises the question of whether it is financially feasible to provide free college education to all students. the document warns against the idea of 'free' federally funded college and suggests it may be too good to be true.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags: 
- 'free' refers to free state university tuition
- 'federally funded college' refers to college education funded by the federal government

Tweet: Don't limit people access, limit vehicle access. When I first visited YNP in 1973, the eastern third of the valley was closed to cars and serviced only by the propane powered buses. I remember riding on the roof of the bus in total awe, cruising along quiet roads, getting off at Happy Isles and heading off to Vernal Falls. On a recent summer visits in 2011 and 2014, those same roads have become linear parking lots, with rangers and summer employees working as high-paid parking lot attendants. In other NPs I have seem campgrounds filled up with more or less giant RVs, some running generators in the evening. Zion has set a reasonably good example that could be followed in Yosemite, Bryce, Acadia, and many others. Parks should be for people, not people in vehicles.
Wiki:
the document advocates for restricting vehicle access in national parks in order to prioritize people's access to the parks. it suggests that certain areas within yellowstone national park were previously only accessible by propane powered buses, creating a peaceful and enjoyable experience for visitors. however, in recent years, these same areas have become congested with cars, turning the roads into parking lots and creating a negative impact on the visitor experience. the author also mentions the issue of large rvs filling up campgrounds and running generators in the evening, further impacting the natural and peaceful atmosphere of the parks. the document praises zion national park as a good example of vehicle restriction that could be followed by other parks like yosemite, bryce, and acadia. the overall message is that parks should prioritize people's enjoyment over vehicular access. 

ynp: yellowstone national park
rvs: recreational vehicles
nps: national parks
#vehiclerestrictionnationalpark #propanepoweredbuses #highpaidparkinglotattendants

Tweet: It takes a while to change people's behaviors. People didn't start buying bottled water overnight... many thought it was crazy, same with bike commuting. I applaud the city for taking a bold stance. To those who say bikes are dangerous, I'm aware there have been deaths but give me a break. You're telling me a car is somehow safer for a pedestrian? Bikes improve safety (dedicated bike lane build outs slow down drivers), improve public health and give us more mobility options! And the drawbacks are less parking places and slower moving cars... big deal. And for the note by the writer that biking is a 3 season activity... nonsense. Unless there is nasty ice build up everywhere, put on a hat and stop bellyaching. I'm still biking to work even in our unseasonably cold December. And guess what? It's FREE and I get to my destination in 10 minutes instead of 25 if I were walking.
Wiki: the document emphasizes that changing people's behaviors takes time and effort. it applauds the city for taking a bold stance in promoting bike commuting despite initial resistance. the writer dismisses concerns about the dangers of biking and argues that dedicated bike lanes actually improve safety and public health. the document also downplays the drawbacks of biking, such as less parking and slower cars, and refutes the claim that biking is only a 3 season activity. the writer personally enjoys biking to work even in unseasonably cold weather, highlighting the benefits of cost savings and time efficiency. the writer suggests that instead of complaining, people should embrace biking as a viable and convenient transportation option.

Tweet: As a pedestrian, I've found the new bike lanes make me less safe - even if they increase safety for bicyclists. This is because bicyclists tend to use the bike lanes to go the wrong way on a one-way street. Pedestrians must cross through the bike lanes to get across the street, and with bikes coming full-speed in the wrong direction, this creates a serious safety hazard. As for the new bike lane along Columbus Avenue - I rarely see any bicyclists using the lane, as most still prefer the street. The few bicycles I've seen in the lane have, in fact, been going the wrong way.
Wiki: the document discusses the impact of new bike lanes on pedestrian safety in new york. while the bike lanes may increase safety for bicyclists, they also create safety hazards for pedestrians. bicyclists often use the bike lanes to go the wrong way on one-way streets, forcing pedestrians to cross through the bike lanes. this puts pedestrians at risk of being hit by bikes traveling in the wrong direction at full speed. the author also notes that the new bike lane along columbus avenue is not commonly used by bicyclists, as most still prefer to ride in the street. the few bicyclists using the lane have been observed going the wrong way. overall, the new bike lanes are perceived as making pedestrians less safe, despite aiming to improve safety for bicyclists.

This is because bicyclists tend to use the bike lanes to go the wrong way on a one-way street. Pedestrians must cross through the bike lanes to get across the street, and with bikes coming full-speed in the wrong direction, this creates a serious safety hazard. As for the new bike lane along Columbus Avenue - I rarely see any bicyclists using the lane, as most still prefer the street. The few bicycles I've seen in the lane have, in fact, been going the wrong way.
Wiki: the document highlights the negative impact of new bike lanes on pedestrian safety. while the lanes may increase safety for bicyclists, they also present dangers for pedestrians. bicyclists often use the bike lanes to go the wrong way on a one-way street, forcing pedestrians to cross through the lanes and putting them at risk of collisions with bikes traveling in the wrong direction. even on streets with new bike lanes, many bicyclists still prefer to ride in the regular traffic lanes. the few bicyclists using the lanes are often observed going the wrong way. this raises concerns about the effectiveness and safety of the new bike lanes.

Tweet: People are people. Whether they are good or bad (and we all are both at various points in time) has nothing to do with citizenship. Stupid argument. Travel more and the stupidity of this argument, and the ignorance it reflects, become all too apparent. So, my advice to Americans is, get a passport and see the world! It's not that scary - in fact, it's wonderful, as are the people who live in it! Stop being paranoid about the rest of the world. The damage that attitude causes for everyone is huge.
Wiki:
the document emphasizes that people are a mix of both good and bad qualities, and that these qualities have nothing to do with their citizenship. the author argues that the idea that people from other countries are inherently different or dangerous is a "stupid argument" and a result of ignorance. the advice given is for americans to obtain a passport and travel more, as it will help them realize the wonderful nature of people from around the world. the document encourages people to expand their horizons and stop being paranoid about the rest of the world, as this attitude can cause significant harm.

- americans: people from the united states of america

- stop being paranoid: refrain from being overly fearful
- #expandinghorizons: broadening one's

Tweet: Maybe its time to let Greece permanently host the Olympics as they wanted to do anyway. Having worked on the Athens 2004 project, the real problem with regards to tourists visiting the city that were not interested in the Olympics was for a short period of about 20 days. So, the idea that it creates havoc is really not true. The worse aspect about the Olympics is the cost factor for any country. Even those held in the USA were done so at a loss. Politicians love to boast that the country will make tons of money but it is never the case. In the case of Greece, it was a major excuse that along with corrupt politicians brought financial ruin to the country. So if a country is not interested in the status quo of showing off and exploiting its taxpayers, Greece could be made the cenral point of Olympic Games once and for all. Food for thought!
Wiki:
the document suggests that greece should permanently host the olympics, as they have wanted to do anyway. the author, who worked on the athens 2004 project, believes that the idea that hosting the olympics creates havoc is not true, as the real problem only lasted for a short period of about 20 days. the main drawback of hosting the olympics is the cost factor, as even countries like the usa have incurred losses. the author mentions that politicians often claim that the country will make a lot of money from hosting the olympics, but this is never the case. in the case of greece, the olympics were used as an excuse, along with corrupt politicians, to bring financial ruin to the country. the document suggests that if a country is not interested in showing off and exploiting its taxpayers, greece could be made the central point of the olympic games once and for all.

abbreviations expanded:
- usa: united states of america

slang expanded:
- "food for thought" means something to think

Tweet: If any of the dire prediction of a Trump presidency turning into a fascist dictatorship should start to occur, that is the time for the justices of the Court to speak out, in reasoned judicial opinions on actual events. I do not find Justice Ginsburg's comments any less dignified than if one of the more conservative justices were to condemn Ms. Clinton's trustworthiness over her lies about her use of private email servers. The dignity of the court, as well as the appearance of impartiality, is lessened when the justices lower themselves into the political maelstrom.

Tweet: When I moved from the US to Berlin, with its enviable public transportation system, I didn't ride a bike for two years. Then came another couple of years in which I didn't ride in the rain or in the winter. But for years now I ride my bike year round in all weather, except when snow makes riding hazzardous. I'll take my experience and assume that the use of New York's bike lanes will increase in increments over time. It's too early to say that they are merely a 'subsidy for the few.' One person sitting in a gigantic, unwieldy vehicle is still just one person, and that person doesn't have a right to own the infrastructure everyone is paying for, based solely on the virtue of taking up a lot of space. I think the most frustrating thing for car drivers who dislike the bike lanes is that they cannot justify their behavior in a city with so many alternatives to driving. Not in this day and age. The bikers present a slap in the face to every rationalization for driving a car.
Wiki:
the document discusses the author's experience of transitioning from using public transportation in berlin to riding a bike year-round in all weather conditions. the author believes that new york's bike lanes will gradually increase in usage over time and suggests that it's too early to dismiss them as just a subsidy for a few people. the document also argues that individuals driving large vehicles do not have the right to monopolize the infrastructure that everyone pays for. the author suggests that car drivers in a city with many alternative transportation options cannot justify their behavior and that bikers challenge the rationalizations for driving a car.

expansion of abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- us (united states)
- hazzardous (hazardous)
- nyc (new york city)
- #bikelanes (bike lanes)

Tweet: Mass. already has a statute permitting civil commitment for addictions. (MGL c .123, sec. 35) so his legal advisors didn't do their homework here. What we don't have are the beds for rehab.. We don't need another law; the tools are already in place for the courts to use their coercive powers; the court clinicians who advise the judges, however, are frustrated by the lack of places to put people who need the nonexistent beds.
Wiki:

Tweet: If the Koch lanes had stayed in place, NY would have developed a bike culture years ago. He quit too soon. The key is segregating bikes from cars. The cement barriers of the Koch lanes would have defined the boundaries and let everyone know where they belonged and did not belong. Establishing bike only cross town and north-south streets would tick off motorists, but certainly create safer transportation. It is time for change. Cyclists need to be as accountable as cab drivers when they do stupid, and the rest of us need to learn how to deal with positive change.
Wiki:
the document argues that if the koch lanes had remained in place, new york city would have developed a bike culture years ago. the key to this is segregating bikes from cars, and the cement barriers of the lanes would have defined these boundaries. the author suggests establishing bike-only cross-town and north-south streets, which may anger motorists but would create safer transportation. it is time for change, and the document emphasizes the need for cyclists to be as accountable as cab drivers when they make mistakes, and for others to learn how to deal with positive change. 

expansion of abbreviations, slang, and hashtags: 
- "koch lanes" refers to the bike lanes implemented by mayor ed koch in the 1980s. 
- "ny" stands for new york. 
- "tick off" means to anger or irritate. 
- "stupid" refers to irresponsible behavior by cyclists. 
- "the rest of us" refers to non-cyclists or the general population

Tweet: Churches SHOULD do this, employers SHOULD do that, insurance companies SHOULD do this! Wiki:
the document implies that everyone, including churches, employers, and insurance companies, should take action to address various societal issues. however, it criticizes individuals who are overweight, suggesting that they are the ones responsible for increasing healthcare costs. the document also states that weight loss can be achieved without spending money, by simply walking more and eating less.

expanded phrases and sentences:
the document suggests that churches should take certain actions, employers should take certain actions, insurance companies should take certain actions, and everyone should take certain actions, except for individuals who are overweight. it implies that the responsibility for increasing healthcare costs falls on those who weigh too much.

the document also mentions that weight loss can be achieved without spending money, by simply walking more and eating less. this implies that there are simple and cost-effective ways for individuals to work towards a healthier weight.

Tweet: I was a French major my first two years at Villanova, and then dropped it, believing it was not practical. A few years later, the pharmaceutical company I was working for merged with a French company. I ended up living in France for 9 wonderful years, and the base provided by my high school and college classes gave me a great foundation for speaking the language and understanding the culture. I see the elimination of foreign language classes as one more sign of the dumbing-down of America. C'est dommage.
Wiki:
the document discusses the experience of a person who initially studied french in college but dropped it due to practicality concerns. however, later in their career, they ended up living in france for 9 years after their company merged with a french company. they attribute their ability to adapt and succeed in france to the foundation provided by their high school and college language classes. they criticize the elimination of foreign language classes in america and express disappointment in this trend.

c'est dommage. = it's a shame.

pharmaceutical company = a company that produces and sells pharmaceutical drugs and medications.

merged = combined or joined together.

foreign language classes = classes that teach languages from other countries.

dumbing-down = the

Tweet: I think we cloud the issue when we talk about learning another language. For people who will never spend more than a few weeks in a Spanish speaking or Francophone country, spending the time to learn to speak the language is of dubious worth. Learning to read and perhaps write the language is altogether another matter. If you can read Spanish, French, etc, you can read the untranslated material from each country. (Translations are always poor.) This would allow you to much better understand the world from their point of view. I no longer speak French very well, but can understand it and read it without too much difficulty. This is sufficient, and does not require a degree.
Wiki:
in the document, the author argues that learning to speak another language may not be necessary for those who will only spend a short time in a country where that language is spoken. however, learning to read and possibly write the language can be very valuable. the author believes that being able to read untranslated material from other countries allows for a better understanding of their perspective, as translations are often not as accurate. the author also shares their personal experience of no longer speaking french fluently, but being able to understand and read it without difficulty, which they consider sufficient and not requiring a degree.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- francophone: a person who speaks french as their first language or as a native language
- etc: et cetera, used to indicate that there are other similar things that could be mentioned
- #learninganotherlanguage: learning to speak a language that is not one's native language

Tweet: New York's bike lanes are off to a great start but still have a long way to go in terms of safety. Car owners here are beginning to get the idea about bicycles but still quite often traverse into bike lanes without looking or without caring. If we really want a cleaner, healthier city then we need to limit the number of automobiles driven here. I also see plenty of cyclist commuters in the winter months. I myself am one. Cycling should be treated as a annual endeavor. Limiting it to warmer temperatures would prove to be dangerous and fatal for a number of riding commuters and enthusiasts. And in general cyclists are a friendly bunch and I'm sure would be willing to work with business owners to facilitate their needs as well.

Tweet: As a University professor in New York I feel protected by the laws that do not permit concealed or open carry of firearms. Tweet: Governor Jerry Brown has made it clear in his State of the State message that he wants HSR. Much less effect of earthquakes the deeper you go underground. Peninsula cities need to stop the NIMBYism and plan for tunnels to mitigate the disruption of elevated Berms. replace dangerous-street-level-loud Caltrains with pedestrian/bicycle greenway over the tunnels. BART was impossibly expensive too, but the longer we waited the more the price grew. A new freeway is more expensive. $200/trip for 30 years doesn't sound so bad compared to all the jobs and development around train stations. We have to grow out of our difficulties is a worthy investment in public resources in my opinion. I applaud our leaders who are making this work!

Tweet: The scarcity argument is so tiresome. We remain the wealthiest country in the world. There is no scarcity of funds; there's a lack of willingness to spend those funds on things like education. The elephant in the room here is college sports programs. (I can't believe none of the contributors to this debate even mentioned it!) Universities with elite athletic programs--and their numbers are great--are FLUSH with cash, much of it provided by taxpayers, private donors (usually alumni), and corporate donors (the latter two also being taxpayers with choices about how their incomes are spent). Meanwhile, the academic departments go begging, almost literally, for scraps. I will not listen to another ideologue tell me how "the taxpayers can't afford _____________ 'entitlement'" when our priorities are as skewed as they are. The taxpayers--and all those private donors--can afford PLENTY; it's what they're willing to spend it on that's the problem. I can't take someone seriously who claims, essentially, that qualified students shouldn't have affordable or free tuition because of football.
Wiki:
the document argues that the scarcity argument is tiresome because, despite being the wealthiest country in the world, there is no scarcity of funds. the real issue is a lack of willingness to spend those funds on important things like education. the document points out that the real problem lies in the prioritization of funds towards college sports programs, which are thriving with cash from taxpayers, private donors (usually alumni), and corporate donors. at the same time, academic departments struggle to acquire necessary funds. the document criticizes the skewed priorities that favor sports over academics and calls out those who claim that taxpayers can't afford entitlements, arguing that they can afford plenty, but it's a matter of what they're willing to spend it on. the document expresses frustration with the idea that qualified students should be denied affordable or free tuition because of the focus on college football. 

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded:
- flush: thriving with cash
- ideologue: an adherent of an ideology,

Tweet: The scarcity argument is so tiresome. We remain the wealthiest country in the world. There is no scarcity of funds; there's a lack of willingness to spend those funds on things like education. The elephant in the room here is college sports programs. (I can't believe none of the contributors to this debate even mentioned it!) Universities with elite athletic programs--and their numbers are great--are FLUSH with cash, much of it provided by taxpayers, private donors (usually alumni), and corporate donors (the latter two also being taxpayers with choices about how their incomes are spent). Meanwhile, the academic departments go begging, almost literally, for scraps. I will not listen to another ideologue tell me how "the taxpayers can't afford _____________ 'entitlement'" when our priorities are as skewed as they are. The taxpayers--and all those private donors--can afford PLENTY; it's what they're willing to spend it on that's the problem. I can't take someone seriously who claims, essentially, that qualified students shouldn't have affordable or free tuition because of football.
Wiki:
the document argues that the scarcity argument is tiresome because the country is still wealthy, and there is no scarcity of funds, but a lack of willingness to spend those funds on education. the writer points out that the real issue lies in the excessive amount of money poured into elite college sports programs, funded by taxpayers, private donors (usually alumni), and corporate donors. this leaves academic departments struggling for funding. the writer expresses frustration with the skewed priorities and argues that taxpayers and private donors can afford to fund education, but it's the choices of what they are willing to spend it on that is the problem. the writer dismisses the idea that qualified students should not have affordable or free tuition because of football. we need to allocate funds to education instead.

(expansion of abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- flush: having an abundant supply of money
- plenty: a sufficient amount
- entitlement: government-funded benefits
- ideologue: a person who strongly advocates a specific

Tweet: Anne, I believe this discussion is wrongly focused. A university that does not offer study in major languages,classics, or theater is in a sorry state. The value of offering study in the humanities should not need defending. The question, "should the humanities be preserved?", is absurd and offensive. A more proper question for the state of New York is "should SUNY Albany be preserved?". Seriously. SUNY suffers more than 60 campuses. The elimination of the humanities at one of the larger SUNY locations is a wake up call. It is time to consolidate the sprawling SUNY system so that the surviving campuses can operate competently. No one can foresee when a degree in the humanities will become "hot" again. SUNY Albany has chosen to ransom its future. So be it.
Wiki:
the document is arguing that a university that does not offer studies in major languages, classics, or theater is in a sorry state. it emphasizes the value of offering study in the humanities and criticizes the question of whether the humanities should be preserved as absurd and offensive. the document suggests that instead of questioning the preservation of the humanities, the more important question is whether suny albany should be preserved. it criticizes suny for suffering and suggests that it is time to consolidate the sprawling suny system so that the surviving campuses can operate competently. the document also criticizes suny albany for eliminating the humanities, stating that it has chosen to ransom its future.

suny - state university of new york
# - hashtag
suny albany - state university of new york at albany

Tweet: If people can be involuntarily committed to psychiatric illness because of a mental illness and substance abuse is a mental illness, of course they should be committed as well. As a LCSW I have seen hundreds of people come to the hospital to detox and then refuse rehabilitation and then come back for detox, refuse rehabilitation....
Wiki: the document argues that if people can be involuntarily committed to psychiatric facilities due to mental illness, then they should also be committed for substance abuse, which is considered a mental illness. the author, who is a licensed clinical social worker (lcsw), has observed many individuals repeatedly seeking detox but refusing rehabilitation. this pattern of behavior indicates the difficulty in treating drug addiction and the challenges in providing long-term support for individuals struggling with substance abuse.

Tweet: I'm as big of an environmentalist as they come and support massive investments in public transportation projects. But I'm worried that the resources going into this project arent wise. I think I'd rather see that same amount of money spent on vastly improving local public transit projects around CA. Specifically, money should be spent to: - improve and expand CalTrain and BART service in the Bay Area. - develop bus rapid transit in the Bay Area, Sacto, LA and San Diego - improve and expand LA's commuter train service Local transit projects like these could probably take more cars off the road, and provide just as many construction jobs, as the high speed train.
new_topic: funding existing public transit in california

Tweet: I would offer the experience of my alma mater, Amherst College. When I was at Amherst (Class of 1961), the school was all male and had fraternities (I was a member of Chi Phi). When the college went coed, it required the fraternities to go coed as well. That did not go well at all, and the result was that Amherst abolished all fraternities. A better choice would have been to add sororities to campus life.
Wiki:
the document shares the experience of the author's alma mater, amherst college, which was an all-male school with fraternities when the author attended in 1961. when the college became coed, the fraternities were required to also become coed, leading to a negative outcome and the eventual abolishment of all fraternities. the author believes that a better decision would have been to add sororities to campus life.

expansion:
- alma mater refers to the school the author attended, amherst college.
- all male refers to a school that only admitted male students at the time.
- fraternities refer to social organizations for male students.
- coed refers to a school that admits both male and female students.
- sororities refer to social organizations for female students.

Tweet: As an addiction medicine physician I think it would be worthwhile to force treatment on addicts if their use is a danger to self and others. I have worked all over the country and one state that allows this already is South Carolina. I can sign papers as a doctor and mandate treatment. Treatment for substance abuse is effective if it's voluntary and also if its involuntary. Sometimes patients left to make their own decision will not make the right one and will not do on their own so it's a way of getting the thousands of people who really need treatment to treatment. In most cases it's not a moral hazard for a hospital . Hospitals may file papers for force substance abuse treatment but quite often the individual would go to another facility elsewhere. Because there is an drug epidemic and that opiate overdose is the leading cause of death over motor vehicle accidents in young people in this country something must be done . Just like mandatory seat belts in all US states the same could be argued for mandatory substance abuse treatment
Wiki:
the document discusses the idea of mandating treatment for drug addicts who pose a danger to themselves and others. as an addiction medicine physician, the author believes that involuntary treatment can be effective in getting addicts the help they need. they have seen success with this approach in south carolina, where they can sign papers as a doctor to mandate treatment. they argue that voluntary treatment is not always effective, as some patients may not make the right decisions on their own. they also believe that mandating treatment is not a moral hazard for hospitals, and that it is necessary in the face of the current drug epidemic. they compare it to the implementation of mandatory seat belts in all us states, arguing that the same could be argued for mandatory substance abuse treatment.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- i can: i can sign papers
- opiate: opioid
- us: united states
- hashtag: #
- drug addict: individual struggling with substance abuse

Tweet: John Wilkes Booth murdered Abraham Lincoln because Lincoln advocated giving the rights of citizenship to black Americans. Our problem is that the members of the Supreme Court that ruled to stop enforcing the Voting Rights Act do not have Civil War Veterans in their families. Their families were in Europe in the 1860's, not on the blood-soaked American battlefields where slavery was abolished with heavy caliber rifles. We have a constitution. We need a Supreme Court that is willing to enforce the Constitution.

Tweet: I share these concerns but I believe that the problem lies in a misalignment of the 9 justices with the body politic, and that this is the result of 30- and 40-year tenures of modern justices. The solution is term limits for justices. Every president should nominate 1 justice in each of the 1st and 3rd years of his or her term, save only when either a justice has retired or died during that period (and the sitting president has made a nomination) or when the turnover has been so great that no justice has served less than 15 years. The longest serving justice would become a senior justice to make way for a new appointment every two years. This would mean that the composition of the court would never lag politics by more than 5-10 years. It would also mean that the justices would be more cautious about taking radically new directions (like destroying the voting rights act and campaign finance regulation) in view of any majority they assemble to rewrite the law inevitably dissolving in much less than a generation. This arrangement would preserve judicial independence while knocking individual justices off the thrones they currently occupy.
Wiki:
the document discusses the problem of long tenures for modern justices, which has led to a misalignment with the body politic. the solution proposed is to implement term limits for justices. the suggestion is that every president should nominate a new justice in the first and third years of their term, except in certain circumstances. the longest serving justice would become a senior justice, allowing for a new appointment every two years. this would ensure that the composition of the court reflects current politics and prevents justices from holding their positions for too long. additionally, it would make the justices more cautious about making major changes to the law, as any majority they assemble would dissolve in a relatively short time. this system would maintain judicial independence while preventing individual justices from holding onto their positions indefinitely.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:

- "1st and 3rd years" = first and third years
- "save only" = except 
- "thrones" = positions of power

Tweet: It's sad to me that the most common defense of her statements appears to me to be, "conservative justices have done it too." She chose to further dismantle it.

Tweet: I commute to work by bicycle every morning up 1st ave, and every evening home down 2nd. I have done so every day, year-round for over a decade. Before that in Boston, Chicago, and Rome. Had a couple close calls riding over the last 25 years, but nothing extraordinary. To date, nothing has threatened my life with greater intensity or frequency than the consequences of these bike lanes. They are death traps for cyclists, pure and simple. NYC bike lanes have been paved with good intentions... that's the best I can say about them.
Wiki:
the text describes the author's experience commuting to work by bicycle in new york city. they have been riding their bike along 1st avenue in the morning and 2nd avenue in the evening for over a decade, as well as in other cities like boston, chicago, and rome. the author has had a couple of close calls while riding but nothing out of the ordinary over the past 25 years. however, they believe that the bike lanes in nyc are dangerous for cyclists and pose a greater threat to their life than any other experiences they have had while riding. the author feels that the bike lanes are "death traps" and suggests that they have been implemented with good intentions but are ultimately harmful.

abbreviations and slang expanded:
- nyc: new york city
- bike lanes: lanes designated for cyclists on the road
- i: i commute to work
- ave: avenue

hashtags expanded:
- #bikelanes: bike lanes designated for cyclists on the road.

Tweet: It's strange that Christians can read the Bible and not see how many times the concept of "marriage" has changed. Abraham repeatedly had his wife Sarah "marry" other men in order to obtain advantages over those men (so much for prohibitions against committing adultery). Jacob, aka Israel, had two wives simultaneously and king Solomon had 700, but by New Testament times a man was only allowed one wife. Mosaic law allowed men to obtain divorces from their wives and remarry, but Jesus (who supposedly did not change one "jot or tittle" of the law) said that this was adultery in most cases. Clearly "the meaning of sex and marriage within the cosmic order" in relationships within the Bible itself was changeable. It seems an odd thing to hold "the meaning of sex and marriage within the cosmic order" to be fixed and unalterable now when it was not so in the past, and it is needlessly cruel to use this concept as a means of hurting loving, committed same-sex couples.
Wiki:
the knowledge from the document is that the concept of marriage has changed throughout the bible. in the past, abraham and jacob had multiple wives, while mosaic law allowed men to divorce and remarry. however, by new testament times, monogamy was the norm. this shows that the meaning of sex and marriage within the cosmic order was changeable within the bible itself. it is suggested that it is odd to hold the meaning of sex and marriage to be fixed now when it was not so in the past, and using this concept to hurt loving, committed same-sex couples is needlessly cruel.

- "new testament" is expanded to "the new testament"
- "mosaic law" is expanded to "the law of moses"
- "jot or tittle" is not an abbreviation or slang
- "the meaning of sex and marriage within the cosmic order" is not

Tweet: Baby sitting deadly radioactive waste for 100,000 years makes nuclear power a bad bargain and using an accrual system of accounting renders power companies and the government actuarily bankrupt. Also, the supply of uranium is limited. We are mining lower and lower grade ore. Also, nuclear reactors belch out radioactive gasses, including tritium, on a daily basis. Nothing is said about this because there is no way to capture tritium.

the document argues that the long-term management of deadly radioactive waste, the limited supply of uranium, and the ongoing release of radioactive gasses from nuclear reactors make nuclear power a poor choice. using an accrual system of accounting also leads to financial instability for power companies and the government. additionally, it points out that there is no way to capture tritium, one of the radioactive gasses emitted by nuclear reactors.

in summary, the document suggests that the long-term management of radioactive waste, limited uranium supply, ongoing release of radioactive gasses, and financial instability make nuclear power an undesirable option.

Tweet: Nuclear energy only provides 8% of U.S. energy. We could easily conserve 8% and then begin the decommissioning of every nuclear power plant. Then we could take the BILLIONS and BILLIONS of dollars thrown at the nuclear industry and invest it in Renewable Energies like Wind and Solar Energy. Germany is HUGELY successful with Wind and Solar Energy. Germany has produced the energy-equivalent of 20 nuclear power plants (yes 20!!) with Solar Energy alone! They are having the same success with Wind Energy. This success in Renewable Energy proves how obsolete and unnecessary nuclear energy is.
Wiki: the document argues that nuclear energy only accounts for 8% of u.s. energy and suggests that this could be easily conserved, leading to the decommissioning of all nuclear power plants. the document also proposes investing the billions of dollars currently spent on the nuclear industry into renewable energies like wind and solar energy. it points to germany as an example of a country that has had huge success with wind and solar energy, producing the energy-equivalent of 20 nuclear power plants with solar energy alone. the document concludes that the success of renewable energy proves that nuclear energy is obsolete and unnecessary.

Tweet: Mandatory voting is the dream of the well financed campaign. Voters who don't care and aren't going to bother learning anything about the issues are going to be the ideal targets for campaign ads designed not to inform, but to simply build a meaningless yet favorable association between the voter and the candidate. Promoting voter turnout is only of benefit to society if those voters are educated voters.
Wiki: the document argues that mandatory voting is the goal of well-funded political campaigns, as they can target uninformed and apathetic voters with campaign ads designed to create a positive but shallow association with the candidate. it asserts that promoting voter turnout is only beneficial if the voters are educated and informed about the issues. in other words, the document suggests that mandatory voting could lead to a higher number of uninformed and unengaged voters participating in the electoral process, which could have negative consequences for society.

Tweet: Simply put as long as NATO lives Turkey will be the core element of it. Strategically and militarily Turkey is far more important than Israel, Germany or Saudi Arabia. And it will be needed more and more in coming years w/o any question.
Wiki: the document emphasizes that as long as the north atlantic treaty organization (nato) exists, turkey will be a critical component of it. the author argues that strategically and militarily, turkey holds more importance than israel, germany, or saudi arabia. the only alternative for nato in the long run, according to the author, is the united kingdom. the author suggests that when considering factors such as geography, gross domestic product (gdp), population growth projections, and potential future conflict zones, turkey's significance within nato becomes even more apparent. the document also posits that nato was established before the writer was even born, and emphasizes the increasing need for the organization in the coming years. in the document, nato is an abbreviation for the north atlantic treaty organization, gdp stands for gross domestic product, and w/o is slang for "without". there are no hashtags in the document.

Tweet: I could not agree more, having lost friends and family members to addiction. This is not as some believe a violation of civil liberties--no one is less free than the addict. Tom, this "mere injection of a substance" as you put it destroys lives, turns people into into monsters who literally steal from their own families. I have seen so many people end up in prison or die from this. You can't imagine the helplessness of family and friends as they watch someone fall prey to addiction, powerless to intervene. I'm no fan of the prohibition of soft drugs but in the case of opiate, crack, and meth addiction, *enough.*
Wiki: the document expresses strong support for heavy drug prohibition, particularly in the case of opiate, crack, and meth addiction. the author emphasizes the devastating impact of addiction, including the loss of friends and family members. they refute the idea that drug prohibition violates civil liberties, arguing that addicts are actually the ones who are least free. they describe the destructive effects of addiction, including turning individuals into "monsters" who harm their own families and often end up in prison or dying. the author also highlights the helplessness felt by family and friends as they watch a loved one struggle with addiction. they clarify that while they may not support the prohibition of softer drugs, they believe that the severe consequences of addiction to substances like opiates, crack, and meth warrant strong legal measures.
