Tweet: I think it was Churchill who said that democracy is the second worst form of government devised by man. What's the worst? Everything else. Our democracy suffers from some serious dysfunctions as the writer notes but I'd be hesitant to entrust nine (actually 5) unelected, usually pretty disconnected jurists in black robes the power to ... well, keep expanding their power. Whether you consider any particular ruling open-minded or open-hearted or reactionary or downright evil or righteous, history is strewn with the corpses of societies which fail to improve their democracy and, instead, turn to a select cabal to make critically important decisions. You wouldn't even have to keep money out of politics if we worked harder at educating our electorate so that they understand the extent to which the rich and powerful, and their toadies in government, manipulate our fears and our wants to avoid what THEY fear get what THEY want. To think that those who are already part of the mightiest of the power elite will ever do what's necessary to protect those who are not part of the power elite is delusional, if not worse.
Wiki: the document expresses a belief that democracy, while flawed, is still better than any other form of government. the writer is hesitant to give too much power to unelected judges, as history has shown that societies suffer when important decisions are made by a small group of elites. the document also suggests that educating the electorate is important for preventing the rich and powerful from manipulating the government for their own benefit. the concept of the "power elite" refers to those who already hold significant influence and control in society. in this context, the "power elite" includes the rich and powerful, as well as their allies in government. the document also implies that those in this "power elite" are unlikely to work in the interests of those who are not part of their group.

Tweet: The bike lanes are an epic fail. I see bikes going the wrong way down the street every day, NOT using the bike lane. the author is advocating for reallocating funds from bike lanes to the mta and improving transportation in the city. they are frustrated with the behavior of some cyclists and believe that the current bike lane system is not effective.

Tweet: "Forcing people to participate who do not want to does nothing to get at the underlying substance of democracy." Amen. In fact, it seems anti-democratic to mandate participation. One of the greatest freedoms is the freedom to be left alone.

Tweet: Apparently, everyone needs to see the film Judgment at Nuremberg, based on transcripts of those trials. Tweet: Since when is NATO a force for democracy or human rights? NATO was formed as a Western alliance against the Soviet threat to take over the world. The Soviet Union is gone. Russia is just a diminutive regional power. Russia doesn't even have an opposing ideology -- it has fully embraced crony capitalism. NATO is showing its true purpose at last: maintain the Western imperial hegemony. Turkey is an important an anti-Russian outpost. Who cares if Turkey does not recognize its own Armenian genocide? Who cares if it stole the country that Kurds were supposed to have and then tried to obliterate the Kurdish identity altogether? Who cares if it nurtured the Syrian civil war? Who cares if it suffocates its own democratic institutions as it transitions into Putin-like authoritarianism? We need Turkey to stick to the Russians. Come to think of it, this makes as much sense as having Russia join NATO to stick it to the Turks. It all depends on who we really want to dominate.
Wiki: the document argues that nato was formed as a western alliance against the soviet threat, but since the soviet union has collapsed and russia is only a small regional power, nato's true purpose is to maintain western imperial hegemony. it highlights turkey as an important anti-russian outpost, disregarding its actions such as not recognizing the armenian genocide, taking the country that kurds were supposed to have, and attempting to obliterate kurdish identity. the document questions the importance given to turkey's role in sticking it to the russians, suggesting that it is as senseless as having russia join nato to oppose the turks. it ultimately raises the question of who the dominant force really wants to be.

Tweet: Removing the essay section from the SATs sends a terrible message to high school students: writing is not that important. If it were, then we'd test for it and an essay would be required. As a communication consultant to Fortune 500 companies, I see everyday executives who can express themselves in writing. I also see those who struggle to get coherent thoughts on a page. Guess what? Those who write well tend to be the more successful business leaders. The message the SATs should send is to tell students that the ability to construct a coherent and supported paragraph or short essay is critical to business success. Unless you want to be a tradesman, writing will probably have a place in your career. Message to SAT: bring the essay back! Loraine Antrim
Wiki:
the document argues that removing the essay section from the sats sends a negative message to high school students about the importance of writing. the writer, loraine antrim, who works as a communication consultant to fortune 500 companies, emphasizes the significance of writing skills in the business world. she believes that the ability to construct a coherent and supported paragraph or short essay is critical to business success and that students should be encouraged to develop their writing skills. the document advocates for bringing back the essay section to the sats to convey the message that writing ability is essential for career success.

expand the abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:

sats- scholastic assessment test
fortune 500- top 500 companies listed by fortune magazine
loraine antrim- the name of the author of the document

Tweet: What dreamland is this guy living in? Why is the onus only on the motor vehicle driver, when they are in their lanes, and going very slowly in Manhattan,(now more than ever because of constricted lanes), and getting ticketed for not obeying traffic rules. Try saying that about cyclists; not in lanes, going the wrong way in lanes, not obeying traffic lights and signs. And do you think the cyclist is at fault when there's an accident? Of course a driver's insurance is going to go up! So let's level the playing field. Let's require license, registration and insurance for bicycles and their users. If they want to share the road, they should share the responsibility.
Wiki:
the document "what dreamland is this guy living in?" is expressing frustration at the perceived unfairness in traffic enforcement in new york city. the author feels that motor vehicle drivers are being unfairly targeted for traffic violations, while cyclists are not held to the same standards. the author suggests that cyclists should be required to have a license, registration, and insurance, just like motor vehicle drivers, in order to share the road responsibly.

the document is advocating for more equal treatment in traffic enforcement, and for cyclists to be held accountable for their actions on the road. the author believes that this will help to level the playing field and improve safety for all road users.

Tweet: One thing that nobody seems to be asking, and that no source seems to have made available (quite possibly because nobody knows) is what Mr. Fenton was wearing. Tweet: Some have questioned whether a gun-carrying woman with a gun pressed against her head would have prevailed had she drawn her weapon. We don't know, but it seems doubtful. Many college students love parties, binge drinking and the problems (including anger, fights and sexual abuse) created by those situations. College students also face emotional problems that do or can lead to suicide, and a gun is the easy exit choice -- as it was many years ago when a college freshman friend of mine took his life. Troubled high school and college students are frequently in the news for causing mayhem and carnage on campus. Generally those so inclinded use surprise as a strategy. We don't know the outcomes if other students and teachers packed weapons. Speculation is easy. What outcome if the law required every person over 17 to carry a loaded weapon? Do we really want to find out? At a controversial football game, would someone kill the umpire? Doug Giebel Big Sandy, Montana

Tweet: The right to vote is already protected in many ways. That said, it is also one of the greatest privileges offered to the American people, and the idea that a privilege should not require some effort to take advantage of has wrongly become embedded in too much commentary in this country. We have freedom of speech, legally protected, but with political correctness rampant in our universities and communities, and people (often from the same disadvantaged groups complaining about voting rights) demonstrating and shouting down any opinions but theirs, I have to say that protection of folks relative to laws is a meaningless protection at best. Indeed, if those folks worried about voting rights took as much time voting and making sure they can as they did demonstrating about it, there would not be a problem with peoples ability to vote at all. And don't even get me started on government overreach at being big brother that makes us afraid to say anything in public, out loud, or online. So much for free speech! Let's protect voting the same way????!!!!!

Tweet: People used to have to have children in their teens and 20s because people didn't live very long and if they were to pass on their genes, they had to get to it early. Tweet: Milliennials burdened by college debt? They chose to take out that debt. Nobody forced them to do that. They made a choice to go into serious debt and now they must accept it and figure out how to deal with it. That's part of the growing up thing. Before they selected a college to attend, they should have sat down with their parents and determined which college was most affordable for them, not which college would be the grooviest to attend. Most of the issues facing the millennials result from the choices they have made over the course of their lives. Too bad they don't have truly serious issues facing them, like the possibility of being drafted and sent off to fight America's overseas wars. There's an example of somebody else making a choice for you that you have absolutely no choice in the matter, other than defying the law, going to prison (like Muhammad Ali), or leaving the country. I don't today's younger generation has the courage to make those kinds choices because it may disrupt their social media activity.

Tweet: No, don't abolish tenure, just make it more effective by giving tenure only after 4 or 5 years. Teach principals how to deal with ineffective teachers -- how to document, step up observations and evaluations, how to dismiss teachers who are not effective. The problem is that most principals don't know the difference between good and bad teachers. In my 36 years working in schools I observed that the principal usually praised the teachers who most often agreed with and flattered them. Yes, teachers usually do stay in the same job, maybe not in the same location, and it's a good thing if they do. I worked in 5 different schools over my career and the most effective schools had a good mixture of experienced and new teachers. The experienced teachers helped new teachers with discipline and techniques they had learned over the years. The new teachers added new ideas and new theories of education. Combined, they all made for an excellent school culture. I just wonder how much time Mr. Petrelli has spent in classrooms some he graduated from school?
Wiki: the document argues against abolishing tenure but suggests making it more effective by granting it only after 4 or 5 years. it also advocates for providing training to principals on how to deal with ineffective teachers, including documentation, increased observations and evaluations, and the dismissal of ineffective teachers. the author points out that many principals struggle to differentiate between good and bad teachers, often favoring those who agree with or flatter them. it is noted that teachers tend to stay in the same job, which can be beneficial, as experienced teachers can mentor new ones and the combination of both can create an excellent school culture. the writer questions the amount of time mr. petrelli has spent in classrooms since graduating from school. #tenure #teachers #principals #schoolculture #effectiveness #classroomexperience

Tweet: Problem is in Massachusetts (and other places) there is NO where to place these patients/addicts. Sounds like a good idea, (sort of), on camera or in writing, to force people into help but there is no there there. No facilities or beds period. Sort of putting the horse in front of the cart. Build them and then just maybe they will come. Where I live (pop. 230,000), there's exactly one small, public rehab center currently with a 6-8 month wait list. We simply don't have the infrastructure in place to accept (or force) people into receiving help. Honestly I don't think the money nor the will is really there. A lot of lip service from our politicians. I question the Gov's proclamation. Did not anyone on his team do the research to discover we've no place to put them?
Wiki: the document discusses the lack of resources and facilities for drug addicts in massachusetts and other places. it mentions that there is nowhere to place these patients and addicts, creating a situation where it may seem like a good idea to force people into getting help, but there are no facilities or beds available. the author notes that where they live, there is only one small, public rehab center with a 6-8 month waitlist for treatment. they believe that the infrastructure is not in place to accept or force people into receiving help, and doubts the government's commitment to addressing the issue. they question whether anyone on the governor's team did research to discover the lack of resources available for drug addicts.

new_topic: sending people to the site of an emergency
Wiki: the document suggests that it would be a smart decision for the cdc (center for disease control and prevention) to handle the situation at hand. in the case of any other emergency epidemic, such as the flu, it would be unreasonable to send a group of people to the affected area to potentially contract the disease and then spread it around the world. additionally, considering the financial chaos, unrest, and potential security risks, it is predicted that the only people who will attend the event are the athletes, and even they will do so reluctantly.

Tweet: I think it would be wise to have the CDC call this question. If it was any other emergency epidemic (flu), it would be madness to send a group of people to the site to contract the disease, then disperse them to the world to carry it. Add to that the financial disarray, the unrest, and the potential security issues and I think the only people who will attend are the athletes, and they will do so reluctantly.

Tweet: Please name one First World country that does not require a strict I.D. to vote, not to mention the same requirement in numerous Second and even Third World countries. For the left to claim that asking blacks and Latino citizens to provide valid, photo I.D.s, despite the necessity of having such to engage in ordinary life in America, is to say that they are malignantly stupid and detached, as if Algonquin J. Calhoun and Lightnin' were representative of ordinary minority folk.
Wiki:
the document argues that it is common for first world countries to require strict identification for voting, and that the same requirement exists in many second and third world countries as well. it criticizes the left for claiming that asking blacks and latino citizens to provide valid, photo identification is unreasonable, considering that identification is necessary for everyday activities in america. 

the abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document can be expanded into complete phrases and sentences as follows:

i.d. - means "identification"
algonquin j. calhoun and lightnin' - refers to fictional characters or stereotypes
left - refers to the political left
#voterid - refers to the voter identification requirement
blacks and latino citizens - refers to african american and latino individuals

overall, the document supports the idea that a voter identification requirement is reasonable and necessary, and criticizes the left for opposing it.

Tweet: As an employer I would consider my work staff as an image of my business. What image does an obese physical therapist, nurse, or PE teacher send. Or a waiter presenting the dessert menu unable to squeeze through the tables to get to the table. The vast majority of the obese are less healthy because of it. Heavy may not always mean unhealthy stats, but losing the weight won't make them less healthy. It is true that some people lose weight more easily. And losing weight often means feeling hungry and deprived, but it remains a choice. Eat few calories than you use and you lose. I see nothing wrong with making folk responsible for choices they make. I wear glasses, pretty blind without them....legally so. Should I demand that folk accept my status if I chose not to accept the responsibility of wearing glasses, their expense, discomfort etc.? I could not read directions, find the proper door..... My disability would, uncorrected, make me less valuable. No employer should be expected to hire less than the best for any position.
Wiki:
the document discusses the importance of considering the image of the work staff as a reflection of the business. it questions the image of employees in certain professions, such as obese physical therapists, nurses, pe teachers, or waiters, and how it may affect the perception of the business. the document also addresses the correlation between obesity and health, emphasizing that while heavy does not always mean unhealthy, losing weight can lead to improved health. it mentions that some people may have an easier time losing weight and that it ultimately comes down to personal choice and responsibility. the document concludes by stating that individuals should be held responsible for the choices they make, using the example of wearing glasses as a personal responsibility. it argues that employers should not be expected to hire anything less than the best for any position.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags expanded into complete phrases and sentences:
- pe teacher: physical education teacher
- i see nothing wrong with making folk responsible for choices they make: i believe that individuals should be held

Tweet: This is frankly stupid. Coercion and attitude years the addict are two different things. Ultimately, addicts either die or *are* coerced by circumstance. It is much better for society to show some tough love than to do the nanny-pamby thing, which leaves so many dead.
Wiki:
the document argues that coercion and attitude towards drug addicts are different things. it suggests that ultimately, addicts either die or are forced into treatment by their circumstances. the document advocates for society to show tough love rather than being overly nurturing, which it believes leads to many deaths among addicts.

Tweet: 'Nonprofit' is a misnomer mainly used in the USA. The rest of the English-speaking world typically talks about 'not-for-profits'. Interestingly, the IRS also uses extensively the term 'not-for-profit', apparently interchangeably with 'nonprofit'. All nonprofits and not-for-profits need to aim to do better than break even, and create at least a small surplus, in a fiscal year in order to buffer them against a loss in the next. Think of Joseph and the seven lean years that followed the fat years. As Steinberg points out, a firm that is a nonprofit or not-for-profit cannot distribute the profit to shareholders. The issue is clouded by the fact that most Americans and others evidently don't understand what a nonprofit or not-for-profit is.
Wiki:
the document discusses the difference between the terms "nonprofit" and "not-for-profit", and how the irs uses them interchangeably. it also emphasizes the importance of not-for-profits creating a surplus in order to protect against future losses. the term "surplus profit" refers to the small surplus that these organizations should aim to create. it is important to note that a nonprofit or not-for-profit cannot distribute this surplus to shareholders. the document also highlights the lack of understanding surrounding the concepts of nonprofit and not-for-profit organizations.

expanded abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- irs: internal revenue service
- surplus profit: a small surplus created by nonprofits and not-for-profits
- not-for-profit: a type of organization that aims to do better than break even and create a surplus
- nonprofit: an organization that is not operated for the purpose of making a profit
- #nonprofit #notforprofit #surplusprofit #irs

Tweet: This city is being destroyed by cars and their pollution. The no idling laws are never enforced and drivers obliviously idle while making cell phone calls or sleeping or doing any number of things. Bikes have a zero carbon footprint or as close to it as you can get. Why are we deferring to the drivers? why is a 3000 pound hunk of toxic gas emitting metal more important than a bike. The bike is clearly superior in that it respects the environment creating no air or noise pollution.To revert back to a bike lane free city is to go back into the dark ages of this city. The paradigm must change.Drivers need to realize that one person on a bike is just as important as one person in a car.They are just two people trying to get where they are going..one quietly and the other creating a swath of noise and filth behind them. It is selfish and unfair for a single driver in a vehicle to insist that they deserve more of the street than the thousands who have risked their lives to do their part to help save the environment. LONG LIVE THE BIKE LANES!!!!! BRAVO, MAYOR!!!
Wiki:
the document argues that cars and their pollution are destroying the city, and the lack of enforcement of no idling laws is a major issue. it questions why drivers are prioritized over bikers, when bikes have almost no carbon footprint and do not create air or noise pollution. it calls for a change in mindset, where drivers and bikers are seen as equals on the road. the document expresses support for the creation and maintenance of bike lanes in new york city. it commends the mayor for their efforts in promoting and expanding bike lanes.

expanded abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:

- idling laws: laws that prohibit leaving a vehicle's engine running when it is not in use
- bravo, mayor: praise for the mayor's actions and decisions regarding bike lanes
- long live the bike lanes!!!!!: an enthusiastic declaration of support for the bike lanes in new york city

Tweet: I don't think we need an amendment. What we need are policies to make it as easy as possible to vote. No more nonsense such as moving polling places off college campuses. limiting voting hours to narrow windows of time, decreasing the number of polling places so people must wait hours to vote, and any other shifty tactics I'm missing in this list. These are the tactics that make me increasingly uneasy about the integrity of elections in the U.S.
Wiki: the document argues against the need for a constitutional amendment to ensure the right to vote, instead emphasizing the importance of implementing policies that make it easier for people to vote. it criticizes tactics such as moving polling places off college campuses, limiting voting hours, and decreasing the number of polling places, which the author views as undermining the integrity of elections in the u.s. the author calls for an end to such tactics and for measures to ensure greater access to voting.

Tweet: I don't believe computers will ever replace humans. Because of the mere facts that computers are programmed by humans. For example, surgical robots are set up to perform complicated surgical cases, but yet; surgeons are the one controlling their moves during surgery. I welcome the artificial help from technology, but they need humans as much as we need them.
Wiki: the document argues that computers will never fully replace humans because they are programmed by humans. for instance, surgical robots are programmed to perform complex surgeries, but surgeons still control their movements during the surgery. the author acknowledges the usefulness of technology, but emphasizes that humans are still essential for the functioning of these artificial systems. therefore, the document supports the idea that humans are necessary in conjunction with technology, and cannot be replaced by it. abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document have been expanded into complete sentences.

Tweet: While I don't support seeing college as only a place of professional training, even from a professional standpoint it is short-sighted to argue that we don't need many of the programs schools think about cutting. Take French for example. While not a major language here in the US, it is spoken in large parts of Africa and is an official language of most of the major international organizations including the UN. In fact, in my work as a project manager with an international public health organization, it was actually my French studies that were the MOST directly relevant part of my academic background, and fluent French were highly valued for their language skills.
Wiki:
the document argues that college should not be viewed solely as a place for professional training, and suggests that it is short-sighted to argue for the cutting of many programs. the example of french is used to illustrate this point, as it is spoken in many parts of africa and is an official language of major international organizations including the united nations. the author also shares their personal experience as a project manager with an international public health organization, emphasizing the value of their fluency in french. the document conveys the importance of learning languages in school and how they can be directly relevant to one's professional work.

expansion:
- un: united nations
- us: united states

Tweet: as a biker in NY for 30 plus years, i am so incredibly happy that the bike lanes are there - and hope that they will eventually be designated on EVERY avenue and selected streets. they make my life so much easier! heavier traffic? well, let drivers learn that they should use public transportation or get onto bikes more! i realize that cars are needed and take taxis OCCASIONALLY myself, but far less frequently thanks to my trusty bike! my biggest complaint? some pedestrians think the new bike lanes are an extra sidewalk for them - and where they are only painted, some cars think that these are terrific spots to pull over for a while - so we are forced to get back into traffic. why don't the police start to ticket these cars and at least hand out warnings to the pedestrians? go bike lanes go!!!!
Wiki:
the document expresses the author's satisfaction with the presence of bike lanes in new york, and their hope for bike lanes to be designated on every avenue and selected streets. the author believes that bike lanes make their life easier and they encourage drivers to use public transportation or bikes. their biggest complaint is that some pedestrians treat the bike lanes as an extra sidewalk and cars use them as parking spots, forcing bikers back into traffic. they suggest that police should start ticketing these cars and warning pedestrians. they show support for the bike lanes with the hashtag #gobikelanesgo.

expanded abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- ny: new york
- occasionally: occasionally
- go bike lanes go!!!!: go bike lanes go! (expressing support and encouragement for the bike lanes)

Tweet: It's already descended just above the level of a soccer match. Why on earth would we want to lower tennis further? I'm for increasing the civility level, forcibly if necessary. The octogenarian ushers at the USOpen, for example, could be armed with taser guns and pepper spray. Or truncheons.
Wiki:
the document expresses concern about the declining civility in tennis matches and suggests increasing the level of civility, even if it has to be enforced. the writer suggests arming the octogenarian ushers at the us open with taser guns, pepper spray, or truncheons to maintain order and civility at the tennis matches.

abbreviation, slang, and hashtags: 
- "#usopen" refers to the united states open tennis championships.
- "taser guns" are electroshock weapons used for subduing individuals by administering non-lethal electric shocks.
- "pepper spray" is a self-defense weapon that dispenses a lachrymatory agent used for riot control and personal self-defense.

Tweet: One of my bicycling habits when returning from a ride in Manhattan I count the number of cyclist crossing the Manhattan Bridge city bound. Seven or eight years ago if there were 40 to 50 cyclists and I deemed that a lot. This past summer the count was more like seventy to eighty. I am on the bridge in mid-morning. These are all young people (I'm in my late sixties) going to work. They are the not the spandex cyclist that appear on the weekend. When I worked the bike took me to the Con ed powerhouses throughout the city. The bike lanes were in there infancy some twenty years ago. Bloomberg has added many miles to them now and our biking population will grow exponentially (I hope!)..
Wiki:
the document indicates that the number of cyclists crossing the manhattan bridge city bound has increased over the past seven or eight years during the mid-morning hour. the author, who is in their late sixties, notes that the cyclists are mostly young people commuting to work, and they are not the typical spandex-wearing cyclists seen on weekends. the author also mentions that when they were working, their bike took them to the con ed powerhouses throughout the city, and that the bike lanes were in their early stages twenty years ago, but have since been expanded by bloomberg. the author expresses hope that the biking population will continue to grow exponentially.

the abbreviations, slang, and hashtags in the document are expanded as follows:
- con ed: con edison
- bloomberg: former new york city mayor michael bloomberg

no specific hashtags were identified in the document.

Tweet: A core example of Kramer's argument is the Bush v Gore decision. If we agree a Court decision is wrong, changing the law or amending the Constitution can fix that.

Tweet: For the record, I was a 1970s-vintage member of a fraternity at a university in the northeast that has been required to become co-ed. I am so angered by the university's decision to require that change that I have terminated all affiliation with both the school and the frat. When last I checked, fraternities were a form of voluntary association. No one was required to join one. No one was required to support their missions, admissions policies or behavior. No one was required to attend their parties. There are programs, groups, departments and activities at every university that I, personally, would want no part of and would avoid like the plague. Because I believe in freedom, however, I would never seek to have them banished. Our colleges and universities brought the plague of political correctness upon us in the first place. The war on frats, because of what it represents, is a new and very dangerous acceleration in the trend to take away our freedoms and replace them with approved group norms. What ever happened to the notion that college was supposed to open your mind to new things and teach you to make and live with choices?
Wiki:
the document expresses the writer's frustration with their alma mater's decision to make their fraternity co-ed, leading to the writer severing ties with both the university and the fraternity. they believe that fraternities and sororities are voluntary associations and no one should be forced to join or support them. the writer criticizes the trend of political correctness on college campuses and sees the push against fraternities as an attack on freedom. they question the idea that colleges should be open to new experiences and choices for students.

- frat: fraternity
- co-ed: co-educational

Tweet: "Yet that same Bible gives us Christians a particular anthropology, and reveals to us the meaning of sex and marriage within the cosmic order." The Bible describes a certain "anthropology," but that doesn't mean the Bible is accurate. You don't HAVE to believe the Bible when it conflicts with reality (which it frequently does). And even if you do choose to ignore reality in order to preserve belief in the Bible, that doesn't give you the right to force the rest of us to ignore reality. Dreher is like someone who watches a magician saw a lady in half, then hears the magician explain how the illusion was achieved, and then still says "Nope, I reject that logical, realistic explanation. It was magic!"

Tweet: Outside of nuclear power for the USNavy, we have never handled nuclear power well or safely, and we have certainly not taken appropriate precautions with mining (see Judith Pasternak's Yellow Dirt, about the disgrace of mining that took place on Navajo lands), or in manufacturing, and Kristen Iversen's Full Body Burden, about Rocky Flats, the plant that made plutonium triggers for nuclear bombs ). That the former Rocky Flats is now, after cursory cleanup, rechristened a wildlife refuge, is a bad joke; during the recent Colorado floods, the old settling ponds spilled over, but no press organization has made any more than a terse mention of that. Many of our Superfund sites were nuclear facilities--badly run, often by influence- peddling contractors; careless about safety; top-notch only at classifying and concealing corner-cutting, errors, and injuries. What has changed that anyone thinks we will do better now? Is there anything in the way government works now that would encourage anyone to think that a renewed nuclear building program would fare any better than the long-ago Washington State Public Power Authority, which never opened a single plant?
Wiki: the document raises concerns about the history of mishandling nuclear power in various industries, including mining on navajo lands and manufacturing at the rocky flats plant. the former rocky flats, now a wildlife refuge, experienced spills during recent floods, but this received minimal media attention. many superfund sites were nuclear facilities poorly managed by influential contractors, leading to safety issues and cover-ups. the document questions whether anything has changed to suggest that a renewed nuclear building program would be any more successful. it questions whether the current government structure would support a better outcome than past failures. #nuclearpower #mining #superfund #rockyflats

Tweet: One must consider that in 1992, the year Ukraine gained independence from the former USSR, it held the world's third largest nuclear weapons arsenal. The government realized it would not be able to property maintain this arsenal and agreed, by treaty, to relinquish it on the basis that the USA and UK agreed to defend its territorial integrity. Even then, the country feared that Russia would attempt to invade or otherwise seize its lands. The unintended message from not assisting Ukraine is that other countries will recognize the importance of nuclear weapons, and will hold on to existing arsenals or attempt to develop one. Such passive encouragement of nuclear arms proliferation is contrary to the stated policy of the Western world to promote the reduction of such weapons. Who will trust the US when approached to eliminate its nuclear arms program?
Wiki:
in 1992, ukraine became independent from the former ussr and held the world's third largest nuclear weapons arsenal. the government realized it could not maintain this arsenal and agreed to give it up in exchange for the usa and uk defending its territorial integrity. however, ukraine still feared invasion or seizure by russia. the lack of assistance to ukraine sends the message that countries should hold onto their nuclear weapons, which goes against the western world's goal of reducing such weapons. this could lead to more countries developing or keeping nuclear arsenals. this raises the question of whether the us can be trusted to eliminate its own nuclear arms program.

abbreviations:
- usa: united states of america
- ussr: union of soviet socialist republics
- uk: united kingdom

slang:
- none

hashtags:
- none

Tweet: Huh? How is this an argument? Dr. Zimbalist says, "They are pass-through entities that pay salaries for their personnel; cover other expenses such as office rent, legal and consulting fees, travel and entertainment; and then distribute any surplus to the teams." How is this any different from any other corporation? Perhaps the overall amount that would be recovered is small, but that is no argument for not doing it. After all, individuals don't have the right to forego paying taxes just because the amount they are paying is trivial when compared to national tax receipts.
Wiki: the document argues that professional sports teams should not be exempt from paying taxes as they operate similarly to other corporations. it suggests that the amount of tax recovered may be small, but this is not a valid reason for not doing so. the comparison is made to individual taxpayers who cannot forego paying taxes simply because the amount is small compared to the national tax receipts. this relates to the policy of taxation and the fairness in applying tax policies to all entities, regardless of size or industry.

Tweet: This is certainly a reasonable essay. Cops need to start writing tickets for all infractions: cars, bikes, and occasionally feet. I don't know how else to get our population to behave more predictably. I love biking in the city, but I cannot go very fast in the bike lanes because sheeple (usually on cell phones), dogs on long leads, and cars (with drivers usually on cell phones) seem to be oblivious. They stagger in and out of our lanes like zombies. I can ride much faster and safer when I ride with the cars in the car lanes. People on cell phones and dogs on long leads are afraid of cars. As a biker, I use that fear to my advantage. The only other way I can imagine getting people to pay attention to where they are, might be to add some heft and/or pointy things to bikes, so that when a pedestrian wanders in front of one they might be impaled or knocked good and hard. That might learn them to look up from their mindless daze.
Wiki:
the document suggests that there is a need for stricter enforcement of traffic laws, including issuing tickets for all kinds of infractions, such as cars, bikes, and even pedestrians. the writer expresses frustration with the lack of predictability in city streets, especially in bike lanes, due to distracted and oblivious individuals. they propose that biking with cars in the car lanes is actually safer, as people on cell phones and dogs on long leads are afraid of cars. the writer also suggests adding weight or sharp objects to bikes as a way to make pedestrians pay more attention and be more cautious. 

the document also references 'sheeple' (a slang term for people who follow others blindly), and uses the hashtag #mindlessdaze, which suggests a state of distraction and lack of awareness. the writer seems to be advocating for a stronger approach to promoting safety and adherence to traffic laws in new york city's bike lanes.

Tweet: The Turkish military was always the standard bearer of Ataturk' policy and secular outlook. Tweet: I am a physics professor at a liber I was tenured as a physics professor at a private liberal arts university about 30 years ago. Over the course of the last 15 years, new hires in physics ( and mathematics too) have been in applied, multidisciplinary fields. Unfortunately, the intellectual challenges presented to research workers in most of these areas are rather minimal. Often current applied research is based on well-understood topics in pure physics and mathematics. It's dull research for minimally-trained scientists. The main benefit to such applied fields is that the intellectual distance between the faculty and the students is narrowing. The other benefit is in grants, contracts, and patents that the military-industrial-pharmaceutical complex makes possible. Thus the faculty now trains little cogs for the benefit of the Empire. The loss of French departments and other humanities departments is just part of the reorganized modern university, which is an instrument of the modern nation state to attain greater wealth and power for some and a stultifying life for most. Where does this madness end?
Wiki: the document discusses the shift in the university curriculum, specifically in the fields of physics and mathematics. the author, a tenured physics professor at a private liberal arts university, laments the trend of hiring new faculty members in applied, multidisciplinary fields, which offer minimal intellectual challenges and often rely on well-understood topics in pure physics and mathematics. this, in turn, results in dull research and the training of minimally-trained scientists. the author also expresses concern about the loss of french departments and other humanities departments, attributing it to the reorganization of the modern university as an instrument of the modern nation state to attain greater wealth and power for some, while leading to a stultifying life for most. the author questions where this trend will lead to. they also criticize the increasing reliance on grants, contracts, and patents from the military-industrial-pharmaceutical complex, which they argue ultimately serves the benefit of the empire.

Tweet: I'm dismayed at the number of comments that miss the point, which is that we need to preserve the integrity of our intellectual tradition. Piecemeal budget cuts are a bad thing. This is not a battle between science and the humanities; it's a battle FOR a flourishing intellectual ecosystem, which is so complex as evolved that, as with the natural ecosystem, we shouldn't be driving niches into extinction. There is no enmity between the sciences and the humanities. They are richly complementary. Anecdote: For some reason, when I was an undergraduate classics major, some of the most well-rounded, thinking students I knew were geology majors. Why geology? Not sure. Maybe because it was West Virginia, where mineral wealth had long been exploited by out-of-state corporations. These geology maors, who were preparing themselves with the scientific understanding to deal with mineral managements, were also intellectually engaged in a most vivid way with their classics and philosophy classes. So the argument isn't necessarily that French departments, or classics or Russian, are there to produce an army of majors. (Just enough to keep the discipline alive.) They are there to enrich everybody.
Wiki:
the document expresses disappointment at the number of comments that do not understand the importance of preserving the integrity of the intellectual tradition. it emphasizes the negative impact of piecemeal budget cuts and argues that it is not a battle between science and the humanities, but rather a battle for a flourishing intellectual ecosystem. the author shares an anecdote about well-rounded geology majors who were also intellectually engaged with classics and philosophy, highlighting the complementary nature of the sciences and humanities. the document stresses that the purpose of departments like french, classics, and russian is not necessarily to produce a large number of majors, but to enrich everyone's education.

- "i'm" expanded to "i am"
- "maors" expanded to "majors"
- "enmity" expanded to "hostility"
- "intellectual ecosystem" expanded to "the network of intellectual disciplines and knowledge"
- "niches" expanded to "specific areas of

Tweet: Please, let us not degenerate into a situation whereby an employer, when faced with two qualified candidates, one obese, one not, MUST hire the obese person or face a lawsuit or penalty! What about the rights of the non-obese candidate? What about the financial repercussions on existing employees, whose medical insurance payments rise even more? And how can an employer expect that an employee will respect his company when that employee clearly doesn't respect his own most valuable possession??? An obese person may feel healthy at the moment, but s/he is living on dwindling organ reserves. One day, things shut down, including the liver, with possible need for a liver transplant and lifelong immunosuppression with attendant complications. The pain of diabetic neuropathy, potential blindness, kidney failure... A person who intentionally puts him- or herself in this position can hardly be a choice possibility as a dedicated employee.
Wiki:
the document raises concerns about the potential requirement for employers to hire obese candidates or face legal consequences. it questions the rights of non-obese candidates and discusses the financial impact on existing employees due to increased medical insurance payments. it also suggests that an obese employee may not respect their own health, raising concerns about their dedication as an employee. the document also highlights the health risks and potential complications associated with obesity. it argues that an obese person may not be a suitable choice for a dedicated employee.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
must - must
s/he - he or she
#obeseemployee - obese employee
immunosuppression - suppression of the immune system
diabetic neuropathy - nerve damage caused by diabetes

Tweet: Yeah, about what I expected from Petrilli. An attempt to seem reasonable by minimizing the problems with his position and overstating the benefits. Yes, an arbitrarily fired teacher without tenure can sue, and might possibly collect... IF he or she can afford a lawyer, and IF he or she can make it through years of litigation without a job. Tenure keeps those arbitrary firings from happening in the first place, while allowing administrators to fire bad teachers where there's actually a reason to do so. It's stupidly simple: tenure is basically a law that says teachers, after several years of service, need to be informed of the reason they're being fired and given a chance to respond to those accusations. Despite a lot of really misleading claims, that's really all it is. And since that system protects good teachers and allows the firing of bad ones, nobody who understands it (and wants the best for kids) will oppose it.
Wiki:
the document argues that tenure provides stability for teachers by preventing arbitrary firings and allowing for a fair process in the case of termination. it suggests that a tenured teacher can only be fired for justified reasons after being given a chance to respond to accusations. the document also criticizes claims against tenure as misleading and argues that those who understand and prioritize the well-being of students should support it.

- administrators can dismiss bad teachers with valid reasons
- tenure ensures that good teachers are protected and bad ones can be fired

Tweet: Here's the bottom line. People with concealed carry permits have been background-checked and vetted by the state, for both character and competence. The question you have to ask yourself is, what is so magical about an imaginary line around a college campus that suddenly changes people who are not a public danger outside that line? If you think that universities are somehow naturally constitution-free zones, this says something about you that you may want to reconsider.

Tweet: I beg to disagree. Students will be called upon to answer essay questions in examinatons. At work, they will draft numerous emails and memoranda. Tweet: It's funny that liberals would endorse government ID programs, but times have changed. When I was young in the late '70s and early '80s, I was adamantly against any type of mandatory government issued ID. I was then and still am a liberal/progressive individual, and I have always been pro-privacy rights. But in today's world, where every entity we deal with in commerce has every speck of data on us, there's really nothing to fight about anymore. In fact, it would be much easier if we all had a government ID. The ID could take the form of a state driver's license or state ID. It must be free to obtain and universally available. It could have a marker on it to show if we are citizens, non-citizens here legally, or non-citizens here for only a period of time. If this were the case, we'd no longer have these debates about IDs and employment, voting, housing, serving on a jury, commerce and travel. The only reason to oppose a national ID is because you want to ensure that people here illegally can still participate in all functions that a citizen can, and that's not a good reason.
Wiki:
the document discusses the changing views on government id programs and the argument for a national id. the author, a self-identified liberal/progressive, used to oppose mandatory government-issued id but now believes it would be beneficial in today's world where our data is already widely available. they suggest that a government id, in the form of a state driver's license or state id, should be free and universally available, with a marker indicating citizenship status. they argue that this would eliminate debates about ids and various functions such as employment, voting, housing, serving on a jury, commerce, and travel. the author also believes that the only reason to oppose a national id is to ensure that people here illegally can still participate in all functions that a citizen can. the author seems to be in favor of a national id as long as it distinguishes between citizens, legal non-citizens, and temporary non-citizens.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- id: identification

Tweet: The Times editorial board confuses political and legal issues in its criticism of Justice Ginsburg. The Supreme Court does not decide political issues. It has based many refusals to consider such issues on its determination that they are political in nature. There is, therefore, no breach of legal ethics when a Justice voices an opinion on a matter of politics. Nothing is more political in nature than the fitness of a candidate to be president, and accordingly, Justice Ginsburg was both within her First Amendment rights as a citizen and the principles of judicial ethics to express her opinion.
Wiki:
the document argues that the supreme court does not decide political issues and has refused to consider such issues as they are deemed political in nature. therefore, it is not a breach of legal ethics for a justice to voice an opinion on a political matter. justice ginsburg was within her first amendment rights as a citizen and the principles of judicial ethics to express her opinion on the fitness of a candidate to be president.

expand the abbreviations, slang, and hashtags: 

- "#scotus" - supreme court of the united states
- "first amendment rights" - the rights guaranteed by the first amendment of the u.s. constitution, including freedom of speech 
- "justice" - a member of the judiciary, particularly a member of the supreme court

Tweet: I am not a believer in "animals' rights". Right to something is a concept developed by humans within their society. But I am against mutilating animals for their owners' convenience, such as declawing a cat, surgically severing the voice chords of a loudly barking dog, cutting horns of goats or trimming the wings of birds. Remember the Golden Rule of Ethics in one of its versions, "One should treat others as one would like others to treat oneself".

Tweet: When Dupont refers to "research," I assume he's referring to his linked report, "Results from the 2013 National Survey on Drug Use and Health," and to Figure 7.10 in that report, the pie chart labeled "20.2 million needing but not receiving treatment for illicit drug or alcohol use," which says that 95.5% said that they "Did not feel they needed treatment." Among the problems with that chart is (1) they don't tell how they defined "needing" or determined who "needed" it (2) they they include marijuana in the category of "illicit drug." The bulk of those 20.2 million could be marijuana users. Even with heroin, amphetamines and cocaine, you can't just assume that because somebody is using that drug, he or she is abusing it or "needs" treatment. Many people function well even while using those drugs. For example, Ayn Rand used amphetamines. Allen Ginsberg used amphetamines. You could spend a whole semester course reading books that had been written on amphetamines. Should they have been forced into treatment?

Tweet: Everytime Hanushek mentions research, watch out. The research he manages to find always seems to reinforce his preferred narrative, no matter how little it resembles reality. Back in reality, tenure is basically a rule that allows the firing of bad teachers while prohibiting the firing of good ones. Like any rule implemented by human beings, it can be derailed by incompetent supervisors, but the rule itself doesn't protect bad teachers. It protects good ones. Ending tenure doesn't make it any easier for a competent administrator to fire a bad teacher, but it DOES make it easier for an incompetent administrator to fire a GOOD teacher. Hanushek is rarely on the right side of issues, and he doesn't surprise here.
Wiki:
the document implies that the notion of ending tenure as a means to improve stability for teachers is not supported by evidence. the statement suggests that tenure does not protect bad teachers, but rather it protects good teachers from being unfairly fired. thus, ending tenure does not improve stability for good teachers, but rather it makes it easier for incompetent administrators to fire good teachers. the document also implies that the research cited by hanushek does not accurately represent the reality of the situation, and reinforces his own biases rather than providing a balanced view.

expansion:
hanushek is known to mention research that supports his preferred narrative, even if it doesn't reflect reality. tenure is essentially a rule that allows the firing of bad teachers, while preventing the firing of good ones. it is susceptible to being mismanaged by incompetent supervisors, but in itself, it doesn't protect bad teachers; it safeguards the good ones. doing away with tenure doesn't necessarily facilitate the dismissal of an incompetent teacher, but it does make it easier

Tweet: The issue is not about all Christians. It is not about all conservative Christians. It is not about all orthodox Christians. It is about a segment of radical Christian fundamentalists that are vigorous in promoting a worldview that is based on a literal reading of some sentences in the Old Testament and are resistant to accepting cultural change and living in a secular society. I am understanding of their dismay and anger - after all, America has become a society where individualism, commercialism, materialism and transnational capitalism have triumphed over community, charity, spirituality and democratic socialism. They feel that they are under attack, just as men did when women received the vote and as whites did in the 1960s who had to live with the Civil Rights Act and the Voting Rights act, which empowered minorities. Radical Muslim fundamentalists form a very small proportion of the world's entire Muslim population, just a radical Muslim fundamentalists form a very small proportion of the world's entire Christian population. Change is inevitable in America, and members of those radical fundamentalist groups are angry and afraid. I understand their emotions, and deplore their actions, be it Orlando or Charleston.
Wiki:
the document discusses a segment of radical christian fundamentalists who promote a worldview based on a literal reading of the old testament and resist cultural change and living in a secular society. this group feels under attack due to societal changes and is angry and afraid. the author compares their emotions to those of men when women received the right to vote and whites in the 1960s when civil rights acts were enacted. the author deplores the actions of these radical fundamentalist groups, such as the events in orlando and charleston.

Tweet: "We want the public to view judicial rulings solely as the product of law and legal reasoning, uninfluenced by political considerations. Acceptance of court rulings is undermined if the public believes that judicial decisions are politically motivated". That boat left the port a long time ago. Certainly after Gore v Bush. A modest correction: Gillers's position might be better phrased as "We want [to be hypocritical and pretend that] the public [ought] to view judicial rulings solely as the product of law and legal reasoning, uninfluenced by political considerations [even when they patently are]. Acceptance of court rulings [as if they were above politics] is undermined if [we acknowledge the truth of the proposition that] the public believes that judicial decisions are politically motivated".
Wiki: this document is discussing the importance of having the public view judicial rulings as solely based on law and legal reasoning, and not influenced by political considerations. it mentions that the acceptance of court rulings is undermined when the public believes that judicial decisions are politically motivated. however, the reader disagrees with this view, suggesting that it is hypocritical to pretend that judicial rulings are not influenced by politics, especially after high-profile cases such as gore v bush. the reader suggests that it is important to acknowledge the truth that judicial decisions can be politically motivated, rather than pretending otherwise. this acknowledges that court rulings can be influenced by political factors, despite the desire for them to be solely based on law and legal reasoning.

Tweet: I would point out that the ability to "freely express his or her ideas" was won for the United States by people carrying, guess what, guns. Tweet: Citizens should absolutely be able to record police activity if they're not obstructing officers from lawful action, and this right should be explicitly codified. The trouble is, many police officers who either don't understand that right or don't want to be videotaped have a way of halting the taping then coming up with reasons why they were justified in doing so -- claiming obstruction or other bad behavior from the citizen, etc. Then the tape comes back empty and you end up with a he-said she-said mess of what actually happened. The advantage of cameras on officers is that when implemented properly, the tape *can't* come back empty. You'll get cases of "I forgot to turn my camera on," of course, but it's a vast improvement over "I had to confiscate the camera because he was impeding police work." And if we're supporting robust citizen videos, two sets of lenses can corroborate what happened better than one.
Wiki: the document argues that citizens should have the right to record police activity as long as they are not obstructing the officers. this right should be officially stated in the law. however, police officers often stop citizens from recording and then come up with justifications for their actions, leading to a he-said she-said situation. the advantage of officers wearing cameras is that the footage cannot be erased. while there may be cases of officers forgetting to turn on their cameras, it is still an improvement over the potential conflicts with citizen recordings. having both police officer and citizen recordings can provide a more accurate account of what took place.

Tweet: Citizens should absolutely be able to record police activity if they're not obstructing officers from lawful action, and this right should be explicitly codified. The trouble is, many police officers who either don't understand that right or don't want to be videotaped have a way of halting the taping then coming up with reasons why they were justified in doing so -- claiming obstruction or other bad behavior from the citizen, etc. Then the tape comes back empty and you end up with a he-said she-said mess of what actually happened. The advantage of cameras on officers is that when implemented properly, the tape *can't* come back empty. You'll get cases of "I forgot to turn my camera on," of course, but it's a vast improvement over "I had to confiscate the camera because he was impeding police work." And if we're supporting robust citizen videos, two sets of lenses can corroborate what happened better than one.
Wiki: the document states that citizens should have the right to record police activity as long as they are not obstructing the officers from their lawful duties, and this right should be explicitly written into law. the problem is that some police officers either don't understand this right, or don't want to be recorded, and may find ways to stop the recording and justify their actions by claiming obstruction or bad behavior from the citizen. this can lead to a situation where there is no evidence of what actually happened. having cameras on officers solves this problem because when used properly, the recording cannot be tampered with. while there may still be cases of officers forgetting to turn on their cameras, this is still an improvement over situations where citizens' cameras are confiscated. additionally, having both officer and citizen recordings can provide better corroboration of what occurred.

Tweet: There are thousands of city residents that ride bicycles for work, such as messengers and food delivery men. I agree that it will take years for regular commuters to switch their mode of transportation to the bicycle, but allowing for this possibility is a great start. Don't forget that bicycle-friendly cities like Amsterdam have a system of public bicycles as well, which helps promote this eco and health-friendly mode of transportation. Finally, if car congestion and revenue for the city are problematic issues, perhaps we can implement a carpool system that only allows free access into Manhattan to cars with multiple passengers and would charge a toll for single drivers.

Tweet: I would be in favor of the following. At least one of the two chambers (presumably the Senate) should ONLY have voters who have graduated from college. Right now, we talk about everyone voting, as if it was some kind of religious ritual like the Sabbath or Ramadhan. But voting is not a religious ritual, it is participation in government making. And those who do not read newspapers and do not understand the issues, should preferably not vote. I know my point of view is unusual, in a society where voting is regarded as a kind of party - the more the better. But perhaps this is an area where skill matters. If most voters had graduated from college, I doubt that we would see Cain or Perry as viable candidates. We complain that they are appealing to ignorant voters, and at the same time we insist that more of the ignorant vote. This is foolish. Of course Democrats have their own banks of ignorant voters, the sin is shared by the parties.

Tweet: The author's opinion of public transit in Los Angeles and San Francisco / Oakland / San Jos鑼 is dated. Both metro areas have good public transit, and getting better. Even if LA's is not currently much used by upper middle class riders, these are not the only people we care about. Moreover, he is badly mistaken when he says that a high-speed rail service "doesn't touch the huge mass of traffic, which swirls daily in the Los Angeles and San Francisco metropolitan areas." Intercity rail and local transit are mutually supportive. Predictably, if high speed trains arrive in downtown LA, more people will use the red, gold and other rail lines to reach their trains than currently do to get to LAX. On the contrary, shifting intercity travel preferences has great potential, especially over time, to shift local travel preferences. Without knowing the author's work, I would further point out that Stanford's record on the study of high speed rail is weak, and that Stanford's professors have been numerous (if short-sighted) in protesting a high-speed rail service that they - probably mistakenly - see as negatively impacting their quality of life. Perhaps get some opinions from UC Irvine?

Tweet: The difference between documented and undocumented is clearly that the documented are identified by official documents while the undocumented are not. Providing ids means that the holders are identified by official documents. While those who applied before coming here are eligible for whatever their documents stipulate those who just showed up have whatever they have been able to take for themselves. De facto the undocumented become documented regardless of whether they followed the official rules or ignored them, and both are effectively officially entitled to act however they have been. Effectively the IDs would make people into legitimate residents and workers, making visas and work permits meaningless obstacles to anyone who wishes to live and to work here. - visas: official permission for someone to enter a country
- work permits: official authorization to work in a country

And NATO's tattered credibility is going to be restored by sitting on the sidelines and tut-tutting while Russia subjugates Ukraine? You can't be serious. If NATO sits by and watches the Russians take over Ukraine, how much confidence will Eastern Europe have in NATO? Do you think that Russia's adventurism will be sated by reducing Ukraine to a vassal state? Putin is riding the tiger he let out of its cage. You know he can't get off. Next it will be the Baltic states and Poland. So here is your only choice: Do you want to take on Putin in Ukraine or in Estonia or Poland?
Wiki:
the document states that it is crucial to restore nato's damaged reputation, and suggests that simply watching russia overrun ukraine will not achieve this. it raises concerns about the potential lack of confidence in nato from eastern europe if it does not take action against russia's aggression. the document also warns that if russia is not confronted in ukraine, it may embolden further aggression in countries like estonia and poland. the speaker urges the reader to consider the choice between confronting putin in ukraine or potentially facing him in other eastern european countries.

(the document does not contain any abbreviations, slang, or hashtags.)

Tweet: I meet the definition of obese. The reason I am obese is that I eat more calories than I burn. On occassion i go on diets and lose lots of weight. My blood pressure falls precipitously and I feel better. If an employer refuses to hire me because I'm fat--yes, fat, that is my problem not his. He didn't heat the extra pizza...I ate it. Why in the world should he be required by law to incur higher medical bills and lost days at work because I decide to stuff my face with pizza or ice cream? It makes no sense any more than it makes sense for people be required by law to pay the health costs for people who acquire a disease because of their voluntary participation in unprotected sex activities or ride motorcycles without helmets or smoke cigarettes. An illness or incapacity acquired like my obesity should not be thrust upon those who are struggling to make ends meet.
new_topic: refusal to hire because of weight
Wiki: the document states that the author meets the definition of obese because they consume more calories than they burn. they have tried going on diets and have experienced significant weight loss and improved health. they believe that their obesity is their own responsibility and that an employer should not be required to hire them if they are overweight. they argue that it does not make sense for employers or society to incur higher medical bills and lost work days due to their own voluntary choices, such as overeating. they compare it to other voluntary activities that have health risks, such as unprotected sex, riding motorcycles without helmets, or smoking. they believe that the burden of their obesity should not be placed on others who are already struggling financially.

Tweet: I think bike lanes are a very good idea. This will promote more bicycle riding in town and make riding safer. I have been commuting throughout the city for over twenty years and I welcome bike lanes. What I don't like is the design and implimentation of these lanes. We don't need islands separating bike lanes from car lanes. This makes it more dangerous for both rider and pedestrians. Pedestrians are often not looking when they cross through bike lanes. Also, the wasted space of in many areas around Time Square. The Broadway bike lane just stops at 47th Street! What's up with that? It all seems to be designed by someone that is not a seasoned rider. Watch the messengers... Are they using the bike lanes? Not likely....
Wiki:
the document expresses support for the idea of bike lanes in new york city, as a way to promote more biking and increase safety for riders. however, the author criticizes the design and implementation of the bike lanes, particularly the use of islands to separate bike lanes from car lanes, which are seen as making it more dangerous for both riders and pedestrians. the author also criticizes the wasted space in some areas, such as around time square, and the sudden end of the broadway bike lane at 47th street. the author believes that the design of the bike lanes does not seem to consider the perspective of experienced riders, and questions whether messengers are using the bike lanes. overall, the author supports the idea of bike lanes but is critical of their current design and implementation in new york city.

abbreviations, slang, and hashtags:
- implimentation: implementation
- what's up with that?: what is the reason for that?
- messengers: bike messengers
- not likely

Tweet: Delaying the games in Rio and making an international push to beef up Brazil's public health infrastructure--with a particular focus on mosquito-borne illnesses like Zika--would use the Olympic spirit and massive media power for a brilliant purpose. abbreviations and slang in the document:

- rio 2017: suggesting the delay of the 2016 rio olympic games to 2017

Tweet: The only thing that makes bikes in the city absolutely maddening is the fact that bike riders do not obey traffic rules. They just plain don't. Every time I hit the streets on foot I have to dodge a cyclist who is ignoring a red light, riding the wrong way on a one-way street, riding on the sidewalk, making a turn on a red light and on and on. No one monitors them or makes them face the consequences of the hazards they pose. The recent proliferation of bike rental businesses is a sign that the mayor wants this in a bad way. The people who rent cycles to tourists don't bother telling them they aren't allowed to ride on the sidewalks or the footpaths in central Park. The pedicabs are now just as bad and they're carrying naive tourists in the back seat on a ride to catastrophe.
Wiki:
the document highlights the frustration of pedestrians with cyclists in the city who do not obey traffic rules. they often ignore red lights, ride on the wrong side of the street, and use sidewalks, creating hazards for pedestrians. the author also criticizes the lack of monitoring and consequences for these actions, as well as the proliferation of bike rental businesses as a sign of the mayor's encouragement. the author also mentions that rental businesses do not inform tourists about the rules, leading to more sidewalk riding. additionally, the document criticizes pedicabs for their reckless behavior, especially when carrying tourists.

abbreviations and slang:
- "the only thing that makes bikes in the city absolutely maddening" --> the only thing that makes bicycles in the city incredibly frustrating
- "don't" --> do not
- "on foot" --> walking
- "the pedicabs" --> the pedal-powered taxis
- "they're" --> they are
- "hashtags" --> tags used on social media

Tweet: The SAT essay has been made optional so that college doors remain open that would otherwise be closed to the non-literate majority emerging from today's secondary schools. We need only consider the letters written home by the relatively uneducated soldiers of the Civil War, the power of which only a minuscule percentage of today's high school graduates (not to mention so very many in college) could hope to equal. Writing skills are acquired, first of all, through READING ( a lot!) the works of those who write well; and then, through WRITING (a lot!). Neither is possible to any significant degree of success in our public education system, because existing class size would require teachers to devote every single evening until midnight, and then the entire weekend, to reviewing and evaluating their students' writing assignments. An impossible proposition. What is required is a reduction of class size to no more than twenty. As any language educator worth her/his degree and job knows, that is the maximum class size for effective language skills development. Are you laughing already? Of course. In what world is that ever going to happen?
Wiki: the document argues that the sat essay has been made optional to allow opportunities for the non-literate majority coming from today's secondary schools. it highlights the importance of reading and writing skills, which are not adequately developed in the current public education system due to large class sizes. the writer suggests that a reduction in class size to no more than twenty students is necessary for effective language skills development. the document also expresses skepticism about this possibility. the abbreviation reading stands for the act of reading a lot, and writing stands for the act of writing a lot. the slang term "worth her/his degree and job" means someone who is a competent and skilled language educator. the hashtag #highschoolwritingskills refers to the topic of high school writing skills.

Tweet: May whatever providential forces watching over us never allow the chaos of Olympic hosting fall on NYC. We can barely handle the tidal waves of tourists -- it's becoming more and more difficult for we natives to enjoy our own city in the summer. I don't want even to think of what the Olympic games would do to us. I have a suggestion: Antarctica. An international place, lots of room for new construction. Just think what it would do for their economy and tourism. And what about the moon? Just think what that would do for all those poor NASA employees who are now being thrown out of work. But sarcasm aside, perhaps it's time to give up the idea that everybody should get a chance to host. Might it not be better for the IOC to pour its considerable resources into a permanent venue, with all participating countries contributing to its maintenance? But not NYC, please. We've already got the UN; isn't that punishment enough?
Wiki: the document expresses a negative opinion about nyc hosting the olympics due to the large influx of tourists and the difficulty for locals to enjoy their city. the author suggests hosting the olympics in antarctica or on the moon. they also propose the idea of a permanent olympic venue supported by participating countries. the abbreviation 'ioc' stands for the international olympic committee. the slang term 'un' refers to the united nations. and the hashtag 'nyc' means new york city.

Tweet: There seems to be a lot of confusion in the comments about when a Justice recuses themselves. So apparently many of the commenters assume if Donald Trump is elected he will be involved in some breach of law that requires a decision by the SCOTUS? Tweet: While I was getting my doctorate at Harvard, I wrote two articles saying basically the same thing Prof Bauerlein says here. In both cases readers attacked me as reactionary (Tea Partiers would likely call me a Communist) and argued for the importance of abstruse theory. Even though I have a PhD in medieval literature, I wonder if there's any point in saving the humanities at the university level. It's become a sewer. A sewer of fashionable theory. I remember one faculty member at Harvard proudly justifying the decision to give tenure to a woefully underqualified professor of Spanish literature on the grounds that the department "needed" an openly gay professor who could teach about things like gay pride and gay rage. The two articles I refer to are: "Apartheid in the Curriculum." Harvard Magazine, January-February 1992, p. 14. "A Crit of Lit: Teaching Literature in the Ivory Tower." Perspective, vol. X, no. 3 (April 1993), 8 ff. Reprinted vol. X, no. 5 (summer 1993), 20 ff.
Wiki: the author expresses frustration with the state of the humanities at the university level, noting that their own articles on the subject received criticism and backlash. they argue that the humanities have become a "sewer" of fashionable theory and question the point of saving them. they provide examples of a faculty member justifying the tenure of an underqualified professor based on their sexual orientation rather than their academic qualifications. the author references two of their articles on the topic for further reading. the author received criticism for their views on the humanities, but they stand by their belief that the field has been negatively impacted by the focus on trendy theories and identity politics.

Tweet: Regulation standards, and standards for policing them are two different things. The failure was not that we did not have clear air standards, it was that we relied to much on the companies to enforce them. It is not enough to tell aliens that can not simply cross our borders, or tell people not to take weapons on the planes. We need credible tests and policing on the government side. We check on the TSA and thus detect failures when dummy weapons are planted. We need to do the same diligence for other regulations like emission standards. It is not enough to rely on the honor system when it is not in an entities best interest to comply. John
Wiki: the document emphasizes the difference between regulation standards and the standards for policing them, highlighting the failure of relying too much on companies to enforce regulations. it argues that clear air standards were in place, but there was a lack of credible tests and policing on the government side. for instance, the transportation security administration (tsa) is checked and failures are detected when dummy weapons are planted. the document calls for the same diligence for other regulations, such as emission standards, and stresses that relying on the honor system is not sufficient when entities do not have a strong incentive to comply. it suggests that credible tests and policing are necessary for effective enforcement. #tsa #emissionstandards #aliens #honorsystem.
